If the organization issuing the certificate is not the U.S. Government, and the Subject CommonName (CN) is not a DoD Root CA, or in not an approved External Certification Authority (ECA) root CA (http://iase.disa.mil/pki/eca/Pages/index.aspx), this is a finding.

Rule.title: Cryptographic mechanisms must be implemented on all operating system components to protect from the unauthorized discloser, maintain the confidentiality, and maintain the integrity of information at rest.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Operating systems handling data requiring "data at rest" protections must employ cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure and modification of the information at rest.
Selection of a cryptographic mechanism is based on the need to protect the integrity of organizational information. The strength of the mechanism is commensurate with the security category and/or classification of the information. Organizations have the flexibility to either encrypt all information on storage devices (i.e., full disk encryption) or encrypt specific data structures (e.g., files, records, or fields).
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000405-GPOS-00184, SRG-OS-000185-GPOS-00079</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the operating system to implement cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure of all information at rest on all operating system components. This should be performed at system creation time as attempting to encrypt the system partitions afterward is not a trivial operation.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system prevents the unauthorized discloser, maintains the confidentiality, and maintains integrity of information at rest by using disk encryption.
Determine the partition list for the system with the following command:
# fdisk –l
Check the system partitions to determine if they are all encrypted with the following command:
# more /etc/crypttab
All persistent disk partitions present on the system must have entries in the file. If any disk partitions are missing from the list, this is a finding.
Pseudo-file systems, such as /proc, /sys, and tmpfs are not required to use disk encryption and are not a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must protect against or limit the effects of Denial of Service (DoS) attacks by ensuring the operating system is implementing rate-limiting measures on impacted network interfaces.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>DoS is a condition when a resource is not available for legitimate users. When this occurs, the organization either cannot accomplish its mission or must operate at degraded capacity.
This requirement addresses the configuration of the operating system to mitigate the impact of DoS attacks that have occurred or are ongoing on system availability. For each system, known and potential DoS attacks must be identified and solutions for each type implemented. A variety of technologies exist to limit or, in some cases, eliminate the effects of DoS attacks (e.g., limiting processes or establishing memory partitions). Employing increased capacity and bandwidth, combined with service redundancy, may reduce the susceptibility to some DoS attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Create a direct firewall rule to protect against Denial of Service (DoS) attacks with the following command:
# firewall-cmd --direct --add-rule ipv4 filter IN_public_allow 0 -m tcp -p tcp -m limit --limit 25/minute --limit-burst 100 -j ACCEPT

check.check-content:
Verify that the operating system protects against or limits the effects of Denial of Service (DoS) attacks by ensuring the operating system is implementing rate-limiting measures on impacted network interfaces.
Check the firewall configuration with the following command:
# firewall-cmd --direct --get-rule ipv4 filter IN_public_allow rule ipv4 filter IN_public_allow 0 -m tcp -p tcp -m limit --limit 25/minute --limit-burst 100 -j ACCEPT
If a rule with both the limit and limit-burst arguments parameters does not exist, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All networked systems must have and use SSH for confidentiality and integrity of transmitted and received information as well as information during preparation for transmission.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Without protection of the transmitted information, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and either read or altered.
This requirement applies to both internal and external networks and all types of information system components from which information can be transmitted (e.g., servers, mobile devices, notebook computers, printers, copiers, scanners, and facsimile machines). Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.
Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of organizational information can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical distribution systems) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, then logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000423-GPOS-00187, SRG-OS-000423-GPOS-00188, SRG-OS-000423-GPOS-00189SRG-OS-000423-GPOS-00190</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Install SSH packages onto the host with the following commands:
# yum install openssh-clients.x86_64 # yum install openssh-server.x86_64
Note: 32-bit versions will require different packages.

check.check-content:
Check to see if sshd is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep ssh libssh2.x86_64 1.4.3-8.el7 @anaconda/7.1 openssh.x86_64 6.6.1p1-11.el7 @anaconda/7.1 openssh-clients.x86_64 6.6.1p1-11.el7 @anaconda/7.1 openssh-server.x86_64 6.6.1p1-11.el7 @anaconda/7.1
If the “SSH server” package is not installed, this is a finding.
If the “SSH client” package is not installed, this is a finding.
Check to see if the add is loaded and active with the following command:
# systemctl status sshd systemctl status sshd sshd.service - OpenSSH server daemon Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/sshd.service; enabled) Active: active (running) since Tue 2015-11-17 15:17:22 EST; 4 weeks 0 days ago Main PID: 1348 (sshd) CGroup: /system.slice/sshd.service ??1348 /usr/sbin/sshd -D
If “sshd” does not show a status of “active” and “running”, this is a finding

Rule.title: The operating system must implement non-executable data to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Some adversaries launch attacks with the intent of executing code in non-executable regions of memory or in memory locations that are prohibited. Security safeguards employed to protect memory include, for example, data execution prevention and address space layout randomization. Data execution prevention safeguards can either be hardware-enforced or software-enforced with hardware providing the greater strength of mechanism.
Examples of attacks are buffer overflow attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -q -n -w kernel. exec-shield=1
A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

check.check-content:
Verify that the operating system implements the configuration to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution.
Check the status of exec-shield with the following command:
# sysctl –system | grep kernel.exec-shield kernel.exec-shield=1
If the value for “kernel.exec-shield” is not a “1”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must implement address space layout randomization to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Some adversaries launch attacks with the intent of executing code in non-executable regions of memory or in memory locations that are prohibited. Security safeguards employed to protect memory include, for example, data execution prevention and address space layout randomization. Data execution prevention safeguards can either be hardware-enforced or software-enforced with hardware providing the greater strength of mechanism.
Examples of attacks are buffer overflow attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to implement address space layout randomization to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -q -n -w kernel.randomize_va_space=2
A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system implements address space layout randomization to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution with the following command:
Check the kernel setting for virtual address space randomization with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl kernel.randomize_va_space kernel.randomize_va_space=2
If the value returned is not “2”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Previous versions of software components that are not removed from the information system after updates have been installed may be exploited by adversaries. Some information technology products may remove older versions of software automatically from the information system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.
Set the “clean_requirements_on_remove” option to “1” in the /etc/yum.conf file:
clean_requirements_on_remove=1

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system removes all software components after updated versions have been installed.
Check if yum is configured to remove unneeded packages with the following command:
# grep –i clean_requirements_on_remove /etc/yum.conf clean_requirements_on_remove=1
If “clean_requirements_on_remove” is not set to “1”, “True”, or “yes”, or is not set in /etc/yum.conf, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must verify correct operation of all security functions.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Without verification of the security functions, security functions may not operate correctly and the failure may go unnoticed. Security function is defined as the hardware, software, and/or firmware of the information system responsible for enforcing the system security policy and supporting the isolation of code and data on which the protection is based. Security functionality includes, but is not limited to, establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and setting intrusion detection parameters.
This requirement applies to operating systems performing security function verification/testing and/or systems and environments that require this functionality.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to verify correct operation of all security functions.
Set the “Selinux” status and the “enforcing” mode by modifying the /etc/selinux/config file to have the following line:
SELINUX=enforcing
A reboot is required for the changes to take effect.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system verifies correct operation of all security functions.
Check if SELinux is active and in enforcing mode with the following command:
# sestatus SELinux status: enabled SELinuxfs mount: /selinux Current Mode: enforcing Policy version: 16
If the “Selinux” status is not set to “enabled”, and the “SELinux” mode is not set to “enforcing”, this is a finding.

<VulnDiscussion>Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.
At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged mount commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to generate audit records containing the full-text recording of privileged mount commands.
Add or update the following rules in /etc/audit/audit.rules:
-a always,exit -F path=/bin/mount -F perm=x -F auid>=500 -F auid!=4294967295 -k privileged-mount
-a always,exit -F path=/bin/umount -F perm=x -F auid>=500 -F auid!=4294967295 -k privileged-mount
The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system generates audit records containing the full-text recording of privileged mount commands.
Check for the following system calls being audited by performing the following series of commands to check the file system rules in /etc/audit/audit.rules:
# grep –i /bin/mount /etc/audit/audit.rules
If the command does not return the following output, this is a finding.
-a always,exit -F path=/bin/mount -F perm=x -F auid>=500 -F auid!=4294967295 -k privileged-mount
# grep –i /bin/umount /etc/audit/audit.rules
If the command does not return the following output, this is a finding.
-a always,exit -F path=/bin/umount -F perm=x -F auid>=500 -F auid!=4294967295 -k privileged-mount

Rule.title: The operating system must, at a minimum, off-load rsyslog messages for interconnected systems in real time and off-load standalone systems weekly.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.
Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to, at a minimum, off-load rsyslog messages for interconnected systems in real time and off-load standalone systems weekly.
Add the @<log server name> option to each active message label in “/etc/rsyslog.conf”. Some examples are:
*.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none /var/log/messages *.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none @192.168.12.131:514
Or to capture all log messages and send them to the remote log host:
*.* @@loghost:514

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system, at a minimum, off-loads rsyslog messages for interconnected systems in real time.
Check to see if rsyslog is sending log messages to a remote syslog server with the following command:
# grep "\*.\*" /etc/rsyslog.conf | grep "@" | grep -v "^#" *.info;mail.none;authpriv.none;cron.none @192.168.12.131:514
If each active message label in the file does not have a line to direct log messages to a remote server, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must, at a minimum, off-load audit daemon messages for interconnected systems in real time and off-load standalone systems weekly.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to, at a minimum, off-load ioff-loads audit daemon messages for interconnected systems in real time.
Modify the remote_server option in the “/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf” file to the IP address or hostname of the remote log server:
remote_server = 192.168.1.12

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system, at a minimum, off-loads audit daemon messages for interconnected systems in real time.
Check to see if the audit daemon is sending log messages to a remote log server with the following command:
# grep –i remote_server /etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf remote_server = 192.168.1.12
If the remote serve line does not point to an active log server, or is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The x86 Ctrl-Alt-Delete key sequence must be disabled.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A locally logged-in user who presses Ctrl-Alt-Delete, when at the console, can reboot the system. If accidentally pressed, as could happen in the case of mixed OS environment, this can create the risk of short-term loss of availability of systems due to unintentional reboot. In the GNOME graphical environment, risk of unintentional reboot from the Ctrl-Alt-Delete sequence is reduced because the user will be prompted before any action is taken.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
By default, the system includes the following line in "/etc/init/control-alt-delete.conf" to reboot the system when the Ctrl-Alt-Delete key sequence is pressed:
exec /sbin/shutdown -r now "Ctrl-Alt-Delete pressed"
To configure the system to log a message instead of rebooting the system, add the following line to "/etc/init/control-alt-delete.override" to read as follows:
exec /usr/bin/logger -p security.info "Ctrl-Alt-Delete pressed"

check.check-content:
To ensure the system is configured to log a message instead of rebooting the system when Ctrl-Alt-Delete is pressed, ensure the following line is in "/etc/init/control-alt-delete.override":
exec /usr/bin/logger -p security.info "Control-Alt-Delete pressed"
If the system is not configured to block the shutdown command when Ctrl-Alt-Delete is pressed, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must prevent the use of dictionary words for passwords.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the operating system allows the user to select passwords based on dictionary words, then this increases the chances of password compromise by increasing the opportunity for successful guesses and brute-force attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to prevent the use of dictionary words for passwords.
Add the following line to the “/etc/pam.d/password” file (or modify an existing line to reference the pam_pwquality.so module and set the control flag to required):
password required pam_pwquality.so retry=3

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system prevents the use of dictionary words for passwords.
Check to see if the pam_pwquality module is referenced in the “/etc/pam.d/password” file and if the control flag is set to “required” with the following command:
# head -1 /etc/pam.d/password password required pam_pwquality.so retry=3
If the module is not found in the “/etc/pam.d/password” file, is commented out, or the control flag is not set to required, this is a finding.
If the module is present and has the required flag set, but is not the first line in the “/etc/pam.d/password” file, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The delay between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt must be at least 4 seconds.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Configuring the operating system to implement organization-wide security implementation guides and security checklists ensures compliance with federal standards and establishes a common security baseline across DoD that reflects the most restrictive security posture consistent with operational requirements.
Configuration settings are the set of parameters that can be changed in hardware, software, or firmware components of the system that affect the security posture and/or functionality of the system. Security-related parameters are those parameters impacting the security state of the system, including the parameters required to satisfy other security control requirements. Security-related parameters include, for example: registry settings; account, file, directory permission settings; and settings for functions, ports, protocols, services, and remote connections.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to enforce a delay of at least “4” seconds between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt.
Modify the “/etc/login.defs” file to set the “FAIL_DELAY” parameter to “4” or greater:
FAIL_DELAY 4

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system enforces a delay of at least “4” seconds between console logon prompts following a failed logon attempt.
Check the value of the fail_delay parameter in “/etc/login.defs” file with the following command:
# grep –i fail_delay /etc/login.defs FAIL_DELAY 4
If the value of “FAIL_DELAY” is not set to “4” or greater this is a finding.

Check the value for the delay in “/etc/pam.d/sshd” file with the following command:
# grep –i faildelay /etc/pam.d/sshd auth required pam_faildelay.so delay=4000000
If the module is not found in the “/etc/pam.d/sshd” file, is commented out, the control flag is not set to “required”, or value for delay is not set to “4000000”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Setting the most restrictive default permissions ensures that when new accounts are created they do not have unnecessary access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.
Add or edit the line for the “UMASK” parameter in “/etc/login.defs” file to “077”:
UMASK 077

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system defines default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.
Check for the value of the “UMASK” parameter in “/etc/login.defs” file with the following command:
Note: If the value of the “UMASK” parameter is set to “000” in “/etc/login.defs” file the Severity is raised to a Cat I.
# grep –i umask /etc/login.defs UMASK 077
If the value for the “UMASK” parameter is not “077”, the “UMASK” parameter is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must not allow an unattended or automatic logon to the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Failure to restrict system access to authenticated users negatively impacts operating system security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to not allow an unattended or automatic logon to the system.
Add or edit the line for the “AutomaticLoginEnable” parameter in “/etc/gdm/custom.conf” file to “false”:
AutomaticLoginEnable=false

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system does not allow an unattended or automatic logon to the system.
Check for the value of the “AutomaticLoginEnable” in “/etc/gdm/custom.conf” file with the following command:
# grep –i automaticloginenable /etc/gdm/custom.conf AutomaticLoginEnable=false
If the value of “AutomaticLoginEnable” is not set to “false”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must not allow an unattended or automatic remote logon to the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Failure to restrict system access to authenticated users negatively impacts operating system security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to not allow an unattended or automatic remote logon to the system.
Edit the appropriate “sshd_config” file to uncomment or add the lines for the “PermitEmptyPasswords”, “PermitUserEnvironment”, “HostbasedAuthentication” keywords and set their values to “no”:
PermitEmptyPasswords no PermitUserEnvironment no HostbasedAuthentication no

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system does not allow an unattended or automatic remote logon to the system.
The location of the “sshd_config” file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which “sshd_config” file will be checked with the following commands:
# grep –i permitemptypassword /etc/ssh/sshd_config PermitEmptyPasswords no
If the “PermitEmptyPasswords” keyword is not set to “no”, is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.
# grep –i permituserenvironment /etc/ssh/sshd_config PermitUserEnvironment no
If the “PermitUserEnvironment” keyword is not set to “no”, is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.
# grep –i hostbasedauthentication /etc/ssh/sshd_config HostbasedAuthentication no
If the “HostbasedAuthentication” keyword is not set to “no”, is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must enable an application firewall, if available.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Firewalls protect computers from network attacks by blocking or limiting access to open network ports. Application firewalls limit which applications are allowed to communicate over the network.
Satisfies: SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00231, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00232</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Ensure the operating system's application firewall is enabled.
Install the “firewalld” package if it is not on the system with the following command:
# yum install firewalld
Start the firewall via systemctl with the following command:
# systemctl start firewalld

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system enabled an application firewall.
Check to see if "firewalld" is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep firewalld firewalld-0.3.9-11.el7.noarch.rpm
If the “firewalld” package is not installed, this is a finding.
Check to see if the firewall is loaded and active with the following command:
# systemctl status firewalld – must show that the firewall if loaded and active firewalld.service - firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon
Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/firewalld.service; enabled) Active: active (running) since Tue 2014-06-17 11:14:49 CEST; 5 days ago
If “firewalld” does not show a status of “loaded and active”, this is a finding.
Check if the state of the firewall:
# firewall-cmd --state running
If “firewalld” does not show a state of “running”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Systems with a BIOS must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the system does not require valid root authentication before it boots into single-user or maintenance mode, anyone who invokes single-user or maintenance mode is granted privileged access to all files on the system. GRUB 2 is the default boot loader for RHEL 7, and is designed to require a password to boot into single-user mode, or make modifications to the boot menu.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to encrypt the boot password for root.
Generate an encrypted grub2 password for root with the following command:
# grub-mkpasswd-pbkdf2 Enter Password: Reenter Password: PBKDF2 hash of your password is grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.F3A7CFAA5A51EED123BE8238C23B25B2A6909AFC9812F0D45
Using this hash, modify the “/etc/grub.d/10_linux” file with the following commands to add the password to the root entry:
# cat << EOF > set superusers="root" password_pbkdf2 tejasbarot grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.F3A7CFAA5A51EED123BE8238C23B25B2A6909AFC9812F0D45 > EOF
Generate a new grub.conf file with the new password with the following commands:
# grub2-mkconfig --output=/tmp/grub2.cfg # mv /tmp/grub2.cfg /boot/grub2/grub.cfg

check.check-content:
Check to see if an encrypted root password is set. On systems that use a Basic Input/Output System (BIOS) use the following command:
# grep –i password /boot/grub2/grub.cfg password_pbkdf2 root grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.biglongstring password user1 insecure
If the root password entry does not begin with “password_pbkdf2”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Systems using UEFI must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the system does not require valid root authentication before it boots into single-user or maintenance mode, anyone who invokes single-user or maintenance mode is granted privileged access to all files on the system. GRUB 2 is the default boot loader for RHEL 7, and is designed to require a password to boot into single-user mode, or make modifications to the boot menu.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to encrypt the boot password for root.
Generate an encrypted grub2 password for root with the following command:
# grub-mkpasswd-pbkdf2 Enter Password: Reenter Password: PBKDF2 hash of your password is grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.F3A7CFAA5A51EED123BE8238C23B25B2A6909AFC9812F0D45
Using this hash, modify the “/etc/grub.d/10_linux” file with the following commands to add the password to the root entry:
# cat << EOF > set superusers="root" password_pbkdf2 tejasbarot grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.F3A7CFAA5A51EED123BE8238C23B25B2A6909AFC9812F0D45 > EOF
Generate a new grub.conf file with the new password with the following commands:
# grub2-mkconfig --output=/tmp/grub2.cfg # mv /tmp/grub2.cfg /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg

check.check-content:
Check to see if an encrypted root password is set. On systems that use Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) use the following command:
# grep –i password /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg password_pbkdf2 root grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.biglongstring password user1 insecure
If the root password entry does not begin with “password_pbkdf2”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The operating system must be a supported release.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>An operating system release is considered "supported" if the vendor continues to provide security patches for the product. With an unsupported release, it will not be possible to resolve security issues discovered in the system software.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Upgrade to a supported version of the operating system.

check.check-content:
Severity Override Guidance:
Note: If an extended support agreement provides security patches for the unsupported product is procured from the vendor, this finding may be downgraded to a CAT II.
Check the version of the operating system with the following command:
# cat /etc/redhat-release
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.2 (Maipo) Current End of Life for RHEL 7 is June 30, 2024.
If the release is not supported by the vendor, this is a finding.

Rule.title: System security patches and updates must be installed and up-to-date.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Timely patching is critical for maintaining the operational availability, confidentiality, and integrity of information technology (IT) systems. However, failure to keep operating system and application software patched is a common mistake made by IT professionals. New patches are released daily, and it is often difficult for even experienced system administrators to keep abreast of all the new patches. When new weaknesses in an operating system exist, patches are usually made available by the vendor to resolve the problems. If the most recent security patches and updates are not installed, unauthorized users may take advantage of weaknesses present in the unpatched software. The lack of prompt attention to patching could result in a system compromise.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Install the operating system patches or updated packages available from Red Hat in a timely manner.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system security patches and updates are installed and up-to-date. Updates are required to be applied with a frequency determined by the site or Program Management Office (PMO).
Obtain the list of available package security updates from Red Hat. The URL for updates is https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/. It is important to note that updates provided by Red Hat may not be present on the system if the underlying packages are not installed.
Check the available package security updates have been installed on the system with the following command:
# yum history list | more Loaded plugins: langpacks, product-id, subscription-manager ID | Login user | Date and time | Action(s) | Altered ---------------------------------------------------------------------- --------- 5 | Jaromir ... <jhradilek> | 2015-07-29 15:33 | Install | 1 4 | Jaromir ... <jhradilek> | 2015-07-21 15:10 | Install | 1 3 | Jaromir ... <jhradilek> | 2015-07-16 15:27 | I, U | 73 2 | System <unset> | 2015-07-16 15:19 | Update | 1 1 | System <unset> | 2015-07-16 14:38 | Install |
If package updates have not been performed on the system within the timeframe that the site/program documentation requires, this is a finding.
Typical update frequency may be over-ridden by information assurance vulnerability alert (IAVA) notifications from CYBERCOM.
If the operating system is in non-compliance with the IAVM process, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system time configuration file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. . If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system account, unauthorized modifications could result in the use of a time source that is not in sync with the organizations other systems, or a failure of time synchronization.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to allow only the ISSM (or individuals or roles appointed by the ISSM) to modify the system time configuration file. Set the owner on the “/etc/ntp.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/ntp.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system time configuration file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/ntp.conf” file with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/ntp.conf -rw-r----- 3 root root 26 Apr 19 11:22 /etc/ntp.conf
If the “/etc/ntp.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system time configuration file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. . If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not owned by a system group, unauthorized modifications could result in the use of a time source that is not in sync with the organizations other systems, or a failure of time synchronization.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/ntp.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/ntp.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system time configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/ntp.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/ntp.conf -rw-r----- 3 root root 26 Apr 19 11:22 /etc/ntp.conf
If the “/etc/ntp.conf” file has a group owner other than root this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system time configuration file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. . If the configuration files controlling time synchronization are not protected, unauthorized modifications could result in the use of a time source that is not in sync with the organizations other systems, or a failure of time synchronization.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/ntp.conf” file to “0640” with the following command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/ntp.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system time configuration file has a mode of “0640” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/ntp.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/ntp.conf -rw-r----- 1 root root 3294 Apr 19 11:22 /etc/audit/audit.rules
If the “/etc/ntp.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0640”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have unnecessary accounts.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Accounts providing no operational purpose provide additional opportunities for system compromise. Unnecessary accounts include user accounts for individuals not requiring access to the system and application accounts for applications not installed on the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the system so that all accounts on the system are assigned to an active system, application, or user account. Remove accounts that do not support approved system activities, or allow for a normal user to perform administrative level actions. Document all authorized accounts on the system.

check.check-content:
Verify all accounts on the system are assigned to an active system, application, or user account.
Obtain the list of authorized system accounts from the ISSO.
Check the system accounts on the system with the following command:
# more /etc/passwd root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash bin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologin daemon:x:2:2:daemon:/sbin:/sbin/nologin sync:x:5:0:sync:/sbin:/bin/sync shutdown:x:6:0:shutdown:/sbin:/sbin/shutdown halt:x:7:0:halt:/sbin:/sbin/halt games:x:12:100:games:/usr/games:/sbin/nologin gopher:x:13:30:gopher:/var/gopher:/sbin/nologin
Accounts such as “games” and “gopher” are not authorized accounts as they do not support authorized system functions. Accounts such as “shutdown” and “halt” are not authorized accounts as they allow users with access to the account passwords to perform system activities that must be restricted to individuals with operating system administrative access.
If the accounts on the system do not match the provided documentation, or accounts that do not support an authorized system function are present, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All GIDs referenced in the /etc/passwd file must be defined in the /etc/group file.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a user is assigned the Group Identifier (GID) of a group not existing on the system, and a group with the Group Identifier (GID) is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to any files associated with the group.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the system to define all GIDs found in the “/etc/passwd” file by modifying the “/etc/group” file to add any non-existent group referenced in the “/etc/passwd” file, or change the GIDs referenced in the “/etc/passwd” file to a group that exists in “/etc/group”.

check.check-content:
Verify that all GIDs referenced in the “/etc/passwd” file are defined in the “/etc/group” file.
Check that all referenced GIDs exist with the following command:
# pwck -r
If GIDs referenced in “/etc/passwd” file are returned as not defined in “/etc/group” file, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must display the date and time of the last successful account logon upon a SSH (or other remote access method) logon.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Providing users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred facilitates user recognition and reporting of unauthorized account use.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure SSH to provide users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred by setting the required configuration options in “/etc/pam.d/sshd” or in the “sshd_config” file used by the system (/etc/ssh/sshd_config will be used in the example).
Add the following line to the top of “/etc/pam.d/sshd”:
session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed
Or modify the PrintLastLog line in “/etc/ssh/sshd_config” to match the following:
PrintLastLog yes

check.check-content:
Verify that remote access methods provide users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred.
For SSH (including openssh), check that the last logon time and date is displayed when a user next logs on. This can be set using two different configuration settings.
Check that “pam_lastlog” is used and not silent with the following command:
# grep pam_lastlog /etc/pam.d/sshd session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed silent
If “pam_lastlog” is missing from “/etc/pam.d/sshd” file, or the silent option is present on the line check for the “PrintLastLog” keyword in the sshd daemon configuration file, this is a finding.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which “sshd_config “file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i printlastlog <sshd_config file> PrintLastLog yes
If the “PrintLastLog” keyword is set to “no”, is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All non-interactive/automated processing account passwords must be changed at least once per year or must be locked.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Automated processing accounts are used by the system or an application to perform non-interactive (no human initiation or intervention) logins. While it is preferred that the password for these accounts be locked to prevent direct logon via a human user, this may prevent the account from functioning properly.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Implement a procedure to document all automated processing accounts on the system, to include a schedule to change the account passwords at least once per year.

check.check-content:
Check the “/etc/passwd” file for accounts that have a home directory different than the human users on the system and have an active shell with the following command:
# more /etc/passwd root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash bin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologin … atd:x:101:101:/opt/atd:/bin/bash … smithj:x:501:501:/home/smithj:/bin/bash
Ask the SA or ISSO whether the noted accounts are used for non-interactive/automated application accounts on the system. Check the password aging for all non-interactive/automated application accounts on the system with the following command (with the atd user as the example):
# grep atd /etc/shadow atd:$6$wKAP1RyH$JeCAcEGhSGVlD0J7.AMg.0:14396:1:365:30:35::
If the value for the 5th field is not “365” days or less, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The root account must be the only account having unrestricted access to the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If an account other than root also has a UID of 0 it has root authority, giving that account unrestricted access to the entire operating system. Multiple accounts with a UID of 0 afford an opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Change the UID of any account on the system, other than root, that has a UID of “0”. If the account is associated with system commands or applications the UID should be changed to one greater than “0” but less than “500”. Otherwise assign a UID of greater than “500” that has not already been assigned.

check.check-content:
Check the system for duplicate UID 0 assignments with the following command:
# awk -F: '$3 == 0 {print $1}' /etc/passwd
If any accounts other than root have a UID of “0”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The executable search path for the root account must be the Red Hat default.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes a working directory or relative paths other than a system or application directory, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. If deviations from the default vendor search path for the system are required, or variables are used in lieu of absolute paths, they must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Edit the root users local initialization files ~/.profile,~/.bashrc (assuming root shell is bash). Change any found “PATH” variable settings to the vendor's default path for the root user. Document any required modifications to the root executable search path.

check.check-content:
Verify that the executable search path for root is the vendor default, or that all modifications have been documented.
Log into the root account or assume the root role on the system and check root’s executable search path with the following command:
# env | grep PATH /usr/kerberos/bin:/usr/local/bin:/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/X11R6/bin:/usr/sbin
This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is a finding.
If directories are found in root’s executable search path that do not belong to the system (such as directories under /opt) ask the SA or ISSO for documentation justifying the requirement.

Rule.title: The root accounts library search path must be empty.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>The library search path environment variable(s) contain a list of directories for the dynamic linker to search to find libraries. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, libraries in these directories may be loaded instead of system libraries. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory.
If deviations from the default vendor search path for the system are required, or variables are used in lieu of absolute paths, they must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to use the default root library path by removing all files that modify the root library search path with the following command:
Note: It is strongly recommended that copies of the files under “/etc/ld.so.conf.d/” be made before removing them from the system.
# rm /etc/ld.so.conf.d/*
If the root library search path must be modified from the default to permit the execution of applications the files under “/etc/ld.so.conf.d/” must be documented with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that the library search path for the root user is empty.
Log into the root account or assume the root role on the system and check root’s library search path with the following command:
# echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH
If a path list is returned, and the directories in the search path have not been documented with the ISSO, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The root accounts list of preloaded libraries must be empty.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary. If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded. This variable is formatted as a space-separated list of libraries. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory.
If deviations from the default vendor search path for the system are required, or variables are used in lieu of absolute paths, they must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the “LD_PRELOAD” environment variable from the system with the following command as the root user:
# export LD_PRELOAD=

check.check-content:
Verify that the reloaded libraries variable for the root account is empty.
Check the LD_PRELOAD environment variable is empty or not defined for the root user with the following command:
# echo $LD_PRELOAD
If a path list is returned, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not permit direct logons to the root account using remote access via SSH.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Even though the communications channel may be encrypted, an additional layer of security is gained by extending the policy of not logging directly on as root. In addition, logging in with a user-specific account provides individual accountability of actions performed on the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure SSH to stop user from logging remotely as the root user.
Edit the appropriate sshd_config file to uncomment or add the line for the PermitRootLogin keyword and set its value to no:
PermitRootLogin no

check.check-content:
Verify that remote access using SSH prevent users from logging in directly as root.
The location of the “sshd_config” file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which “sshd_config” file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i permitrootlogin <sshd_config file> PermitRootLogin no
If the “PermitRootLogin” keyword is set to “yes”, is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: System files and directories must not have uneven access permissions.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Discretionary access control is weakened if a user or group has access permissions to system files and directories greater than the file owner.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Change the mode of files with uneven permissions so owners do not have less permission than group or world users, or so that group does not have less permissions than world users.

check.check-content:
Verify that system binaries, configuration files, and directories do not have uneven access permissions.
Check the system files and directories for uneven file permissions with the following command:
# ls -lL /bin /usr/bin /usr/lbin /usr/usb /sbin /usr/sbin /etc | more -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7660 Feb 26 2009 accton -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 5896 Mar 10 2011 addpart -r-xrwxr-x 1 root root 10497 Jan 6 2007 adsl-connect
If any of the system binaries, configuration files, or directories have group permissions greater than the owner, or have world permissions greater than the owner or group, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All files and directories must have a valid owner.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Un-owned files and directories may be unintentionally inherited if a user is assigned the same UID as the UID of the un-owned files.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Either remove all files and directories from the system that do not have a valid user, or assign a valid user to all unowned files and directories on the system with the chown command:
# chown <user> <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all files and directories on the system have a valid owner.
Check the owner of all files and directories with the following command:
# find / -xdev -nouser
If any files on the system do not have an assigned owner, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All files and directories must have a valid group-owner.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Files without a valid group owner may be unintentionally inherited if a group is assigned the same Group Identifier (GID) as the Group Identifier (GID) of the files without a valid group-owner.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Either remove all files and directories from the system that do not have a valid group, or assign a valid group to all files and directories on the system with the chgrp command:
# chgrp <group> <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all files and directories on the system have a valid group.
Check the owner of all files and directories with the following command:
# find / -xdev -nogroup
If any files on the system do not have an assigned group, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have unapproved file or directory extended ACLs.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>File system extended ACLs provide access to files beyond what is allowed by the Unix mode setting on files and directories. Files and directories that have unapproved extended ACLs may provide unintended, or surreptitious access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the extended ACLs for all files on the system with the following command:
# setfacl -RLb /
If extended ACLs are required document all output from the following command with the ISSO:
# getfacl –aL <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that there are no files with extended ACLs on the system.
Check the system for files with extended ACLs with the following command:
# getfacl -Rs /
If the command returns any files with extended ACLs, and the extended ACLs are not documented with the ISSO, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All system command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>System command files include files present in directories used by the operating system for storing default system executables and files present in directories included in the system's default executable search paths. Restricting permissions will protect system command files from unauthorized modification or utilization.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of system command files and directories with modes more permissive than “0755” with the following command:
# chmod 0755 <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all system command files have a mode of “0755” or less permissive.
Check the mode of all system command files on the system with the following commands:
# ls –alL /etc /bin /usr/bin /usr/lbin /usr/usb /sbin /usr/sbin # find / -perm -022 -a -type f -exec ls -ld {} \; DIRS="/etc /bin /usr/bin /usr/lbin /usr/usb /sbin /usr/sbin";for DIR in $DIRS;do find $DIR -type f -perm +022 -exec stat -c %a:%n {} \;;done
If any files are found in the listed directories with a mode more permissive than “0755” , this is a finding.

Rule.title: All system files, programs, and directories must be owned by a system account.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Files associated with the functioning of the operating system should be owned by a privileged account (an account with a UID less than 500), which is normally established during the creation of the system or application installation.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of system command files and directories with an owner with a UID greater than “499” with the following command:
Note: The example uses the root user, which will suffice for most files. Some files on the system may require a user other than root, sys, or bin to restrict their access to other parts of the operating system.
# chown root <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all system command files and directories are owned by a privileged account.
Check the owner of all system command files and directories with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc /bin /usr/bin /usr/lbin /usr/usb /sbin /usr/sbin | more
If any files or directories have an owner with a UID of greater than “499”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Files associated with the functioning of the operating system should be owned by a privileged group (a group with a Group Identifier (GID) less than 500), which is normally established during the creation of the system or application installation.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of system command files and directories with an owner with a GID greater than “499” with the following command:
Note: The example uses the root group user, which will suffice for most files. Some files on the system may have a group user other than root, sys, or bin to restrict their access to other parts of the operating system.
# chgrp root <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all system command files and directories are group owned by a privileged account.
Check the group owner of all system command files and directories with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc /bin /usr/bin /usr/lbin /usr/usb /sbin /usr/sbin | more
If any files or directories have an group owner with a GID of greater than “499”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: System log file directories must have a mode of 0750 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>System log files must be protected against modification or removal by unauthorized users. Many system log files are created with modes that are more permissive than necessary, requiring system administrator intervention to continually re-set them. Setting the mode of the system log file directory (or directories) resolves this issue.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
The standard location for log files will be under the “/var/log” subdirectory. Change the mode on the “/var/log” subdirectory with the following command:
# chmod 750 /var/log
Additional log directories may be found by checking the “/etc/rsyslog”.conf file with the following command:
# more /etc/rsyslog.conf
The chmod command must be applied to those directories as well.

check.check-content:
The standard location for log files will be under the “/var/log” and “/var/adm” subdirectories. Check the location of the log files generated by rsyslog with the following command:
# more /etc/rsyslog.conf *.=crit;kern.none /var/log/critical mail.*;mail.!=info /var/log/mail
Check the permissions on all subdirectories that contain system logs with the following command(s):
# ls –alLd /var/log rwxr-x--- 1 root root 2084 Jul 3 211 log
If any of the log file subdirectories other than those created by rsyslog (such as Xorg) has permissions greater than “0750”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Manual page files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If manual pages are compromised, misleading information could be inserted, causing individuals to perform actions that could lead to a compromise of the system. Manual pages could also be modified to execute malicious code at an elevated privilege level.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the files under “/usr/share/man” and “/usr/share/info” to “0644” with the following commands:
# chmod -R 0644 /usr/share/man # chmod -R 0644 /usr/share/info

check.check-content:
Verify that the system manual page files have a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the files under “/usr/share/man” with the following command:
# ls –alR /usr/share/man/man* -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 817 Jun 9 2014 411toppm.1.gz -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 4644 Mar 6 00:06 a2p.1.gz -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 3523 Jan 9 2013 ab.1.gz
Check the mode of the files under “/usr/share/info” with the following command:
# ls –alR /usr/share/info/* -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 11699 Mar 6 00:05 accounting.info.gz -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 249667 Mar 5 17:25 as.info.gz -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 309960 Jun 10 2014 autoconf.info.gz
If any files under “/usr/share/man” or “/usr/share/info” have a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver. DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses. If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information. DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/resolv.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/resolv.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system DNS resolver configuration file is owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/resolv.conf” file with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/resolv.conf -rw-r----- 3 root root 35 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/resolv.conf
If the “/etc/resolv.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver. DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses. If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information. DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/resolv.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/resolv.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system DNS resolver configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/resolv.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/resolv.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 35 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/resolv.conf
If the “/etc/resolv.conf” file has a group owner other than root this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/resolv.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The resolv.conf (or equivalent) file configures the system's DNS resolver. DNS is used to resolve host names to IP addresses. If DNS configuration is modified maliciously, host name resolution may fail or return incorrect information. DNS may be used by a variety of system security functions such as time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/resolv.conf” file to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/resolv.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system DNS resolver configuration file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/resolv.conf” file with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/resolv.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 35 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/resolv.conf
If the “/etc/resolv.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/hosts file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/hosts file (or equivalent) configures local host name to IP address mappings that typically take precedence over DNS resolution. If this file is maliciously modified, it could cause the failure or compromise of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/hosts.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/hosts.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local DNS resolver configuration file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/hosts.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/hosts.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 35 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/hosts.conf
If the “/etc/hosts.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/hosts file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/hosts file (or equivalent) configures local host name to IP address mappings that typically take precedence over DNS resolution. If this file is maliciously modified, it could cause the failure or compromise of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/hosts.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/hosts.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local DNS resolver configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/hosts.conf” file with the following command: # ls –al /etc/hosts.conf -rw-r----- 3 root root 72 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/hosts.conf
If the “/etc/hosts.conf” file has a group owner other than root this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/hosts file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/hosts file (or equivalent) configures local host name to IP address mappings that typically take precedence over DNS resolution.
