If this file is maliciously modified, it could cause the failure or compromise of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/hosts.conf” file to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/hosts.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local DNS resolver configuration file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/hosts.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/hosts.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 35 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/hosts.conf
If the “/etc/hosts.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/nsswitch.conf file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The nsswitch.conf file (or equivalent) configures the source of a variety of system security information including account, group, and host lookups. Malicious changes could prevent the system from functioning or compromise system security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/nsswitch.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local name service switch configuration file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/ nsswitch.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 99 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/ nsswitch.conf
If the “/etc/ nsswitch.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/nsswitch.conf file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The nsswitch.conf file (or equivalent) configures the source of a variety of system security information including account, group, and host lookups. Malicious changes could prevent the system from functioning or compromise system security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/nsswitch.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local name service switch configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/ nsswitch.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 99 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/ nsswitch.conf
If the “/etc/ nsswitch.conf” file has a group owner other than root this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/nsswitch.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The nsswitch.conf file (or equivalent) configures the source of a variety of system security information including account, group, and host lookups. Malicious changes could prevent the system from functioning or compromise system security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/nsswitch.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local name service switch configuration file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/ nsswitch.conf -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 99 Mar 1 11:22 /etc/ nsswitch.conf
If the “/etc/ nsswitch.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: For systems using DNS resolution, at least two name servers must be configured.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>To provide availability for name resolution services, multiple redundant name servers are mandated. A failure in name resolution could lead to the failure of security functions requiring name resolution, which may include time synchronization, centralized authentication, and remote system logging.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to use two or more name servers for DNS resolution.
Edit the “/etc/resolv.conf” file to uncomment or add the two or more nameserver option lines with the IP address of local authoritative name servers. If local host resolution is being performed the “/etc/resolv.conf” file must be empty. An empty “/etc/resolv.conf” file can be created as follows:
# echo -n > /etc/resolv.conf

check.check-content:
Determine whether the system is using local or DNS name resolution with the following command:
# grep hosts /etc/nsswitch.conf hosts: files dns
If the dns entry is missing from the host’s line in the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file the “/etc/resolv.conf” file must be empty.
Verify that the “/etc/resolv.conf” file is empty with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/resolv.conf -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 0 Aug 19 08:31 resolv.conf
If local host authentication is being used and the “/etc/resolv.conf” file is not empty, this is a finding.
If the dns entry is found on the host’s line of the “/etc/nsswitch.conf” file verify that the operating system is configured to use two or more name servers for DNS resolution.
Determine the name servers used by the system with the following command:
# grep nameserver /etc/resolv.conf nameserver 192.168.1.2 nameserver 192.168.1.3
If less than two lines are returned that are not commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/passwd file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts and associated configuration information. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the”/etc/passwd” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/passwd

check.check-content:
Verify that the local account configuration file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/passwd” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/passwd -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 477 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/passwd
If the “/etc/passwd” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/passwd file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts and associated configuration information. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/passwd” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/passwd

check.check-content:
Verify that the local account configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/passwd” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/passwd -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 477 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/passwd
If the “/etc/passwd” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/passwd file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/passwd file contains the list of local system accounts and associated configuration information. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/passwd” file to root with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/passwd

check.check-content:
Verify that the local account configuration file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/passwd” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/passwd -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 477 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/passwd
If the “/etc/passwd” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/group file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the”/etc/group” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/group

check.check-content:
Verify that the local group configuration file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/group” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/group -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 322 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/group
If the “/etc/group” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/group file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/group” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/group

check.check-content:
Verify that the local group configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/group” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/group -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 322 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/group
If the “/etc/group” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/group file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The group file contains a list of system groups and associated information. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/group” file to root with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/group

check.check-content:
Verify that the local group configuration file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/group” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/group -rw-r--r-- 3 root root 322 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/group
If the “/etc/group” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/shadow” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/shadow

check.check-content:
Verify that the local password configuration file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/shadow” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/shadow -r-------- 3 root root 344 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/shadow
If the “/etc/shadow” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/shadow file (or equivalent) must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. The file also contains password hashes which must not be accessible to users other than root.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/shadow” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/shadow

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local password configuration file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/shadow” file with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/shadow -r-------- 3 root root 344 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/shadow
If the “/etc/shadow” file has a group owner other than root this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must have mode 0400.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. The file also contains password hashes which must not be accessible to users other than root.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on the “/etc/shadow” file to root with the following command:
# chmod 0400 /etc/shadow

check.check-content:
Verify that the system local password configuration file has a mode of 0400.
Check the mode of the “/etc/shadow” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/shadow -r-------- 3 root root 344 Jan 21 11:22 /etc/shadow
If the “/etc/shadow” file has a mode other than 0400, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All interactive users must have a home directory assigned in the /etc/passwd file.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Assign home directories to all interactive users that currently do not have a home directory assigned.

check.check-content:
Verify that interactive users on the system have a home directory assigned.
Check for missing interactive user home directories with the following command:
# pwck -r user 'lp': directory '/var/spool/lpd' does not exist user 'news': directory '/var/spool/news' does not exist user 'uucp': directory '/var/spool/uucp' does not exist user 'smithj': directory '/home/smithj' does not exist
Ask the SA if any users found without home directories are interactive users. If the SA is unable to provide a response check for users with a UID of 500 or greater with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$"
If any interactive users do not have a home directory assigned, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All interactive user accounts, upon creation, must be assigned a home directory.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to assign home directories to all new interactive users by setting the “CREATE_HOME” parameter in “/etc/login.defs” to “yes” as follows.
CREATE_HOME yes

check.check-content:
Verify that all interactive users on the system are assigned a home directory upon creation.
Check to see if the system is configured to create home directories for interactive users with the following command:
# grep –i create_home /etc/login.defs CREATE_HOME yes
If the value for “CREATE_HOME” parameter is not set to "yes", the line is missing, or the line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If an interactive user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given access to the / directory as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a Denial of Service because the user would not be able to access their logon configuration files, and may give them visibility to system files they normally would not be able to access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Create home directories to all interactive users that currently do not have a home directory assigned. Use the following commands to create the user home directory assigned in “/etc/ passwd”:
Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj”, a UID of “smithj”, and a GID of “users assigned” in “/etc/passwd”.
# mkdir /home/smithj # chown smithj /home/smithj # chgrp users /home/smithj # chmod 0750 /home/smithj

check.check-content:
Verify that the assigned home directory of all interactive users on the system exists.
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj
Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files to contain system logon information.
Check that all referenced home directories exist with the following command:
# pwck –r user 'smithj': directory '/home/smithj' does not exist
If any home directories referenced in “/etc/passwd” are returned as not defined, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All user home directories must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Excessive permissions on user home directories may allow unauthorized access to user files by other users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of interactive user’s home directories to “0750”. To change the mode of an interactive user home directory use the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user “smithj”.
# chmod 0750 /home/smithj

check.check-content:
Verify that the assigned home directory of all interactive users has a mode of “0750” or less permissive.
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj
Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files to contain system logon information.
Check the mode on all interactive users’ home directories with the following command:
# ls –al <users home directory> drwxr-x--- 1 smithj users 860 Nov 28 06:43 smithj
If home directories referenced in “/etc/passwd” do not have a mode of “0750” or less permissive, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All interactive user home directories must be owned by their respective users.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a user does not own their home directory unauthorized users could access or modify the user's files, and the users may not be able to access their own files.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of an interactive user’s home directories to that owner. To change the owner of an interactive user home directory use the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# chown smithj /home/smithj

check.check-content:
Verify that the assigned home directory of all interactive users is owned by that user.
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj
Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files to contain system logon information.
Check the owner of all interactive users’ home directories with the following command:
# ls –al <users home directory> drwxr-x--- 1 smithj users 860 Nov 28 06:43 smithj
If user home directory referenced in “/etc/passwd” is not owned by that user, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All interactive user home directories must be group-owned by the home directory owners primary group.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the Group Identifier (GID) of the home directory is not the same as the primary GID of the user, this would allow unauthorized access to the users’ files, and users that share the same group may not be able to access files that they legitimately should.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of an interactive user’s home directory to the group found in “/etc/passwd”. To change the group owner of an interactive user home directory use the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user “smithj”, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj”, and has a primary group of users.
# chgrp users /home/smithj

check.check-content:
Verify that the assigned home directory of all interactive users is group owned by that users' primary GID.
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3,4 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj 250
# grep 250 /etc/group users:x:250:smithj,jonesj,jacksons
Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files to contain system logon information.
Check the group owner of all interactive users’ home directories with the following command:
# ls –al <users home directory> drwxr-x--- 1 smithj users 860 Nov 28 06:43 smithj
If user home directory referenced in “/etc/passwd” is not group owned by that users’ primary GID, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All files and directories contained in interactive user home directories must be owned by the owner of the home directory.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If users do not own the files in their directories, unauthorized users may be able to access them. Additionally, if files are not owned by the user, this could be an indication of system compromise.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of an interactive user’s files and rectories to that owner. To change the owner of an interactive users’ files and directories use the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# chown smithj /home/smithj/<file or directory>

check.check-content:
Verify that all files and directories in a users’ home directory are owned by the user.
Check the owner of all files and directories in a users’ home directory with the following command:
# ls –lLR /<home directory path>/<users home directory>/ /home/smithj -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 18 Mar 5 17:06 file1 -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 193 Mar 5 17:06 file2 -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 231 Mar 5 17:06 file3
If any files are found with an owner different than the home directory user, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All files and directories contained in user home directories must be group-owned by a group of which the home directorys owner is a member.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a user's files are group-owned by a group of which the user is not a member, unintended users may be able to access them.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group of an interactive user’s files and rectories to group that the interactive user is a member of. To change the group owner of an interactive users’ files and directories use the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj”, and is a member of the users group.
# chgrp users /home/smithj/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all files and directories in a users’ home directory are group owned by a group the user is a member of.
Check the group owner of all files and directories in a users’ home directory with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user “smithj”, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj/home/smithj”
# ls –lLR /<home directory>/<users home directory>/ -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 18 Mar 5 17:06 file1 -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj smithj 193 Mar 5 17:06 file2 -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj sa 231 Mar 5 17:06 file3
If any files are found with an owner different than the group home directory user, check to see if the user is a member of that group with the following command:
# grep smithj /etc/group sa:x:100:juan,shelley,bob,smithj smithj:x:521:smithj
If the user is not a member of a group that group owns file(s) in a users’ home directory, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All files and directories contained in user home directories must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a user's files have excessive permissions unintended users may be able to access or modify them.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on files and directories in the users' home directory with the following command:
# chmod 0750 /<home directory>/<users home directory>/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all files and directories contained in a users’ home directory, excluding local initialization files, have a mode of “0750”.
Check the mode of all non-initialization files in a users’ home directory with the following command:
Files that begin with a “.” are excluded from this requirement.
Note: The example will be for the user “smithj”, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj/home/smithj”
# ls –lLR /<home directory>/<users home directory>/ -rwxr-x--- 1 smithj smithj 18 Mar 5 17:06 file1 -rwxr----- 1 smithj smithj 193 Mar 5 17:06 file2 -rw-r-x--- 1 smithj sa 231 Mar 5 17:06 file3
If any files are found with a mode more permissive than “0750”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All run control scripts must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the system startup files are writable by users other than the owner, they could modify the startup files to insert malicious commands leading to unintended system operations.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on run control scripts with the following command:
# chmod 0755 /<directory>/systemd/system/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all system run control scripts have a mode of “0755” or less permissive.
Check the mode for all run control scripts on the system with the following commands:
# ls -alL /etc/systemd/system/ | more -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 176 Jun 9 2014 dbus-org.bluez.service -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 577 Mar 5 18:35 dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 1044 Mar 5 17:03 dbus-org.freedesktop.Avahi.service
# ls -alLR /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 275 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-ccpp.service -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 380 Mar 23 23:56 abrtd.service -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 361 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-oops.service
# ls -alLR /run/systemd/system/ | more -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:14 session-1.scope -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 17 Jun 28 17:01 session-13.scope -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:57 session-10.scope
If any system run control scripts has a mode more permissive than “0755”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Run control scripts executable search paths must contain only approved paths.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. If deviations from the default vendor search path for the system are required, or variables are used in lieu of absolute paths, they must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Document the modified path statement of all run control scripts that require it. Remove the modified path entries from those path statements that do not match the approved documentation.

check.check-content:
Verify the library search paths for system run control scripts.
Check the path statements for all run control scripts on the system with the following commands:
# grep -ir path /etc/system/system/* /etc/systemd/bootchart.conf:#Init=/path/to/init-binary /etc/systemd/journald.conf:#TTYPath=/dev/console
# grep -ir path /usr/lib/system/system/* | more /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/90-default.preset:enable multipathd.service /usr/lib/systemd/system/basic.target:Wants=sockets.target timers.target paths.target slices.target /usr/lib/systemd/system/basic.target:After=sysinit.target sockets.target timers.target paths.target slices.target
# grep -ir path /run/system/system/* | more /run/systemd/generator/dev-mapper-centos\x2dswap.swap:SourcePath=/etc/fstab /run/systemd/generator/boot.mount:SourcePath=/etc/fstab /run/systemd/generator/-.mount:SourcePath=/etc/fstab /run/systemd/generator/systemd-cryptsetup@luks\x2dabcd9dbf\x2d4ea8\x2d45cd\x2db3a5\x2decc835aa3869.service:SourcePath=/etc/crypttab
The commands will return path variables formatted as a colon-separated list of directories.
If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is a finding.
If an entry for a directory that is not owned by a privileged or application user and is not documented, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Run control scripts must not execute world-writable programs or scripts.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>World-writable system startup files could be modified to insert malicious commands leading to unintended system operations.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode on all world writable files referenced by system run control scripts to allow for execution, but not modification, with the following command:
# chmod 0755 <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that system run control scripts are not world writable.
Check the system for world writable files with the following command:
# find / -perm -002 -type f -exec ls -ld {} \; | more
For all files listed check for their presence in the system run control scripts with the following commands:
# grep <file> /etc/systemd/system/ # grep <file> /usr/lib/systemd/system/ # grep <file> /run/systemd/system/
If any system run control scripts are found to reference world writable files, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All run control script files must be owned by root.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>System startup files that are owned by a user other than root files may be modified to insert malicious commands leading to unintended system operations.
If a system startup file must be owned by an application user it must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of all system run control scripts with the following commands:
# chown –R root /etc/systemd/system/<file> # chown –R root /usr/lib/systemd/system/<file> # chown –R root /run/systemd/system/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all files executed by system run control scripts are owned by root or a documented application account.
Check the owner for all run control scripts on the system with the following commands:
# ls -alL /etc/systemd/system/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 176 Jun 9 2014 dbus-org.bluez.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 577 Mar 5 18:35 dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1044 Mar 5 17:03 dbus-org.freedesktop.Avahi.service
# ls -alLR /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 275 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-ccpp.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 380 Mar 23 23:56 abrtd.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 361 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-oops.service
# ls -alLR /run/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:14 session-1.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 17:01 session-13.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:57 session-10.scope
If any file executed by a system run control script is not owned by root, or is owned by an application user and in not documented with the ISSO, this is a finding.

Rule.title: System run control script files must only execute programs owned by a privileged or application user.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>System start-up files executing programs owned by other than root, another privileged user, or an application may be modified to insert malicious commands leading to unintended system operations. If a system startup file must be owned by a non-privileged or application user it must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of all system run control scripts with the following commands:
# chgrp –R root /etc/systemd/system/ # chgrp –R root /usr/lib/systemd/system/ # chgrp –R root /run/systemd/system/

check.check-content:
Verify that all files executed by system run control scripts are owned by a privileged or a documented application account.
Check the group owner for all run control scripts on the system with the following commands:
# ls -alL /etc/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 176 Jun 9 2014 dbus-org.bluez.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 577 Mar 5 18:35 dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1044 Mar 5 17:03 dbus-org.freedesktop.Avahi.service
# ls -alLR /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 275 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-ccpp.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 380 Mar 23 23:56 abrtd.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 361 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-oops.service
# ls -alLR /run/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:14 session-1.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 17:01 session-13.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:57 session-10.scope
If any file executed by a system run control script is not group owned by root, bin, sys, or is group owned by an application user and is not documented with the ISSO, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All global initialization files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon logon. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of all global initialization files with the following commands:
# chmod 0644 /etc/systemd/system/<file> # chmod 0644 /usr/lib/systemd/system/<file> # chmod 0644 /root /run/systemd/system/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all global initialization files have a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode for all global initialization files on the system with the following commands:
# ls -alL /etc/systemd/system/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 176 Jun 9 2014 dbus-org.bluez.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 577 Mar 5 18:35 dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1044 Mar 5 17:03 dbus-org.freedesktop.Avahi.service
# ls -alLR /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 275 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-ccpp.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 380 Mar 23 23:56 abrtd.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 361 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-oops.service
# ls -alLR /run/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:14 session-1.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 17:01 session-13.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:57 session-10.scope
If any global initialization files have a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All global initialization files must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon logon. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of all global initialization files with the following commands:
# chown –R root /etc/systemd/system/<file> # chown –R root /usr/lib/systemd/system/<file> # chown –R root /run/systemd/system/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all global initialization files are owned by root or a documented application account.
Check the owner for all global initialization files on the system with the following commands:
# ls -alL /etc/systemd/system/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 176 Jun 9 2014 dbus-org.bluez.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 577 Mar 5 18:35 dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1044 Mar 5 17:03 dbus-org.freedesktop.Avahi.service
# ls -alLR /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 275 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-ccpp.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 380 Mar 23 23:56 abrtd.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 361 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-oops.service
# ls -alLR /run/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:14 session-1.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 17:01 session-13.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:57 session-10.scope
If any global initialization files are not owned by root, or is owned by an application user and in not documented with the ISSO, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All global initialization files must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Global initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon logon. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of all global initialization files with the following commands:
# chgrp –R root /etc/systemd/system/<file> # chgrp –R root /usr/lib/systemd/system/<file> # chgrp –R root /run/systemd/system/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all global initialization files are group owned by root.
Check the group owner for all global initialization files on the system with the following commands:
# ls -alL /etc/systemd/system/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 176 Jun 9 2014 dbus-org.bluez.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 577 Mar 5 18:35 dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1044 Mar 5 17:03 dbus-org.freedesktop.Avahi.service
# ls -alLR /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 275 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-ccpp.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 380 Mar 23 23:56 abrtd.service -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 361 Mar 23 23:56 abrt-oops.service
# ls -alLR /run/systemd/system/ | more -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:14 session-1.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 17:01 session-13.scope -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 Jun 28 16:57 session-10.scope
If any global initialization files are not group owned by root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All skeleton files (typically those in /etc/skel) must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files or insert malicious commands leading to unintended system operations.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode on all skeleton files to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod –R 0644 /etc/skel

check.check-content:
Verify that all skeleton files have mode “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode on the skeleton files with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/skel -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 18 Mar 5 17:06 .bash_logout -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 193 Mar 5 17:06 .bash_profile -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 231 Mar 5 17:06 .bashrc
If any skeleton files have mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All skeleton files and directories (typically in /etc/skel) must be owned by root or bin.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner of the skeleton files to root with the following command:
# chown -R root /etc/skel

check.check-content:
Verify that the skeleton files are owned by root.
Check the owner of the skeleton files with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/skel -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 18 Mar 5 17:06 .bash_logout -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 193 Mar 5 17:06 .bash_profile -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 231 Mar 5 17:06 .bashrc
If a skeleton file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All skeleton files (typically in /etc/skel) must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files or insert malicious commands leading to unintended system operations. Failure to give group ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner of the skeleton files to root with the following command:
# chgrp -R root /etc/skel

check.check-content:
Verify that the skeleton files are group owned by root.
Check the owner of the skeleton files with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/skel -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 18 Mar 5 17:06 .bash_logout -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 193 Mar 5 17:06 .bash_profile -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 231 Mar 5 17:06 .bashrc
If a skeleton file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All global initialization files executable search paths must contain only absolute paths.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. If deviations from the default vendor search path for the system are required, they must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Edit the global initialization files to change any found PATH variable statements that contain an empty entry. If an application requires a path variables to reference a directory owned by the application is must be documented with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that all global initialization files path statements do not contain statements that will reference the current working directory.
Check the path statement for all global initialization files on the system with the following commands:
# grep –i path /etc/systemd/system/ | more # grep –i path /usr/lib/systemd/system/ | more # grep –i path /run/systemd/system/ | more
If any path statement contains an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All local initialization files must be owned by the home directory user or root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon logon. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner of the local initialization files to either the directory owner or root with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the smithj user, which has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# chown smithj /home/smithj/.*

check.check-content:
Verify that all local initialization files are owned by the home directory user or root.
Check the owner on all local initialization files with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the “smithj” user, which has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# ls –al /home/smithj/.* | more -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 896 Mar 10 2011 .profile -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 497 Jan 6 2007 .login -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 886 Jan 6 2007 .something
If any file that begins with a “.” is not owned by the home directory owner, or root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Local initialization files must be group-owned by the users primary group or root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon logon. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of an interactive user’s home directory to the group found in “/etc/passwd”. To change the group owner of an interactive user home directory use the following command:
Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of “/home/smithj”, and has a primary group of users.
# chgrp users /home/smithj

check.check-content:
Verify that the local initialization files of all interactive users are group owned by that users' primary GID.
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the smithj user, which has a home directory of “/home/smithj” and a primary group of users.
# cut -d: -f 1,3,4 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj 250
# grep 250 /etc/group users:x:250:smithj,jonesj,jacksons
Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files to contain system logon information.
Check the group owner of all interactive users’ initialization files with the following command:
# ls –al /home/smithj/.* -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 896 Mar 10 2011 .profile -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 497 Jan 6 2007 .login -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 886 Jan 6 2007 .something
If all interactive users’ initialization files are not group owned by that users’ primary GID, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All local initialization files must have mode 0740 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Local initialization files are used to configure the user's shell environment upon logon. Malicious modification of these files could compromise accounts upon logon.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the local initialization files to “0740” with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the smithj user, which has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# chmod 0740 /home/smithj/.*

check.check-content:
Verify that all local initialization files have a mode of “0740” or less permissive.
Check the mode on all local initialization files with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the smithj user, which has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# ls –al /home/smithj/.* | more -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 896 Mar 10 2011 .profile -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 497 Jan 6 2007 .login -rwxr-xr-x 1 smithj users 886 Jan 6 2007 .something
If any file local initialization files have a mode more permissive than “0740”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All local initialization files executable search paths must contain only absolute paths.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory (other than the users home directory) executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. If deviations from the default vendor search path for the user are required they must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Edit the local initialization files to change any PATH variable statements that reference directories other than their home directory. If a user requires a path variables to reference a directory owned by the application is must be documented with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that all local initialization files path statements do not contain statements that will reference a working directory other than the users’ home directory.
Check the path statement for all local initialization files in the users' home directory with the following commands:
Note: The example will be for the smithj user, which has a home directory of “/home/smithj”.
# grep –i path /home/smithj/.* /home/smithj/.bash_profile:PATH=$PATH:$HOME/.local/bin:$HOME/bin /home/smithj/.bash_profile:export PATH
If any interactive users’ initialization files have path statements that include directories outside of their home directory, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Local initialization files must not execute world-writable programs.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If user start-up files execute world-writable programs, especially in unprotected directories, they could be maliciously modified to destroy user files or otherwise compromise the system at the user level. If the system is compromised at the user level, it is easier elevate privileges to eventually compromise the system at the root and network level.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode on files being executed by the local initialization files with the following command:
# chmod 0755 <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that local initialization files do not execute world-writable programs.
Check the system for world writable files with the following command: # find / -perm -002 -type f -exec ls -ld {} \; | more
For all files listed check for their presence in the local initialization files with the following commands:
Note: The example will be for a system that is configured to create users home directories in the /home directory.
# grep <file> /home/*/.*
If any local initialization files are found to reference world writable files, this is a finding.

Rule.title: There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, rhosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The .rhosts, .shosts, rhosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system. Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system as it does not require interactive identification and authentication of a connection request, or for the use of two-factor authentication.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove any found .rhosts, .shosts, rhosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files from the system.
# rm [file name]

check.check-content:
Verify that there is no .rhosts, .shosts, rhosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system.
Check the system for the existence of these files with the following commands:
# find / -name ‘*.rhosts’ # find / -name '*.shosts’ # find / -name rhosts.equiv # find / -name shosts.equiv
If any of these commands returns a file on the system, this is a finding.

Rule.title: PAM must not support rsh server authentication.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>.rhosts files are used to specify a list of hosts permitted remote access to a particular account without authenticating. The use of such a mechanism defeats strong identification and authentication requirements.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the rsh-server package from the system with the following command:
# yum remove rsh-server

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not support rsh server authentication.
Check for the presence of rsh configuration files with the following commands:
# grep rhosts /etc/pam.d/rsh auth sufficient /lib/security/pam_rhosts_auth.so # grep rhosts /etc/pam.d/rlogin
If either of the commands return a line that contains "pam_rhosts_auth.so", this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/shells (or equivalent) file must exist.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The shells file (or equivalent) lists approved default shells. It helps provide layered defense to the security approach by ensuring users cannot change their default shell to an unauthorized unsecure shell.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Create the “/etc/shells” file with the following commands:
# touch /etc/shells # chown root:root /etc/shells # chmod 0755 /etc/shells
Modify the “/etc/shells” file to contain the shells that users are authorized to utilize on the system.

check.check-content:
Verify that the /etc/shells file exists.
Check for the existence of the /etc/shells file with the following command:
# cat /etc/shells | more /bin/sh /bin/bash /sbin/nologin /usr/bin/sh /usr/bin/bash /usr/sbin/nologin /bin/tcsh /bin/csh
If nothing is returned by the command, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All shells referenced in /etc/passwd must be listed in the /etc/shells file, except any shells specified for the purpose of preventing logons.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The shells file lists approved default shells. It helps provide layered defense to the security approach by ensuring users cannot change their default shell to an unauthorized unsecure shell. Shells used to disable account access (such as /usr/bin/false, /bin/false, /dev/null, /sbin/nologin, /bin/sync, /sbin/halt, and /sbin/shutdown), and sdshell are considered valid shells for use in the /etc/passwd file, but will not be listed in the /etc/shells file. Application binaries are also not to be listed in the /etc/shells file.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the account is used for interactive logon use the following command:
Note: The example will set the bash shell for user “smithj”.
# chsh –s /bin/bash smithj
Alternately, edit the “/etc/passwd” file and correct the error by changing the default shell of the account in error to an acceptable shell contained in the “/etc/shells” file. If the account is not being used for interactive logon edit the “/etc/passwd” file and give the user a false shell.

check.check-content:
Verify that all valid shells referenced in the “/etc/passwd” file are in “/etc/shells”.
Check the shell entries in “/etc/passwd” file against the “/etc/shells” file with the following command:
# for USHELL in `cut -d: -f7 /etc/passwd`; do if [ $(grep -c "${USHELL}" /etc/shells) == 0 ]; then echo "${USHELL} not in /etc/shells"; fi; done# /bin/false is not in /etc/shells /sbin/nologin is not in /etc/shells /sbin/shutdown is not in /etc/shells
The /usr/bin/false, /bin/false, /dev/null, /sbin/nologin, /bin/sync, /sbin/halt, /sbin/shutdown, (and equivalents), and sdshell will be considered valid shells for use in the /etc/passwd file, but will not be listed in the /etc/shells file. Application binaries may also be referenced in the /etc/passwd file but will not be listed in /etc/shells.
If a shell referenced in /etc/passwd is not listed in the shells file, excluding the above mentioned shells, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All shell files must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If shell files are owned by users other than root or bin, they could be modified by intruders or malicious users to perform unauthorized actions.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the ownership of shell files with incorrect ownership with the following command:
# chown root <shell>

check.check-content:
Verify that all shell files on the system have an owner of root.
Check the ownership of shell files referenced in the “/etc/shells” file with the following command:
# cat /etc/shells | xargs -n1 ls –l -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /bin/sh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /bin/bash -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7168 Mar 6 00:59 /sbin/nologin -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /usr/bin/sh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /usr/bin/bash -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7168 Mar 6 00:59 /usr/sbin/nologin -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 404416 Jun 9 2014 /bin/tcsh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 404416 Jun 9 2014 /bin/csh
If any shell is not owned by root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All shell files must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If shell files are group-owned by users other than root or a system group, they could be modified by intruders or malicious users to perform unauthorized actions.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group ownership of shell files with incorrect group with the following command:
# chgrp root <shell>

check.check-content:
Verify that all shell files on the system have a group owner of root.
Check the group ownership of shell files referenced in the “/etc/shells” file with the following command:
# cat /etc/shells | xargs -n1 ls –l -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /bin/sh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /bin/bash -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7168 Mar 6 00:59 /sbin/nologin -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /usr/bin/sh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /usr/bin/bash -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7168 Mar 6 00:59 /usr/sbin/nologin -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 404416 Jun 9 2014 /bin/tcsh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 404416 Jun 9 2014 /bin/csh
If any shell is not group owned by root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All shell files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Shells with world/group write permissions give the ability to maliciously modify the shell to obtain unauthorized access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the shell file to “0755” with the following command:
# chmod 0755 <shell>

check.check-content:
Verify that all shell files on the system have a mode of “0755” or less permissive.
Check the mode of shell files referenced in the “/etc/shells” file with the following command:
# cat /etc/shells | xargs -n1 ls –laL -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /bin/sh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /bin/bash -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7168 Mar 6 00:59 /sbin/nologin -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /usr/bin/sh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 960384 Mar 5 17:06 /usr/bin/bash -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 7168 Mar 6 00:59 /usr/sbin/nologin -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 404416 Jun 9 2014 /bin/tcsh -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 404416 Jun 9 2014 /bin/csh
If any shell has a mode more permissive than “0755”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: A file integrity tool must be used to check for extraneous or modified device files on the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If an unauthorized device is allowed to exist on the system, there is the possibility the system may perform unintended or unauthorized operations.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to use cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of device files .
Install aide if it is not part of the inventory with the following command:
# yum install aide
Modify the “/etc/aide.conf” file to include the selections lines to include the directories and subdirectories that contain device files.

check.check-content:
Verify that all device files on the system are checked for unauthorized modification.
List all device files on the system with the following command:
Note: Devices files are normally found under “/dev”, but applications may place device files in other directories, necessitating a search of the entire system.
Note: Executing this command may result in large listings of files; the output may be redirected to a file for easier analysis.
# find / -type b -o -type c
Note the directories and subdirectories that device files reside in.
Check to see if aide is installed on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep aide
If aide is not installed ask the system administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system.
If there is no application installed to perform integrity checks, this is a finding.
Note: aide is highly configurable at install time if complied on the system.
These commands assume that the aide.conf file is under the “/etc” directory. Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:
# find / -name aide.conf
Check the aide.conf file to determine whether the directories and subdirectories that contain device files are listed. Individual files can be listed in the aide.conf file as well, but this is not recommended.
If all of the directories and subdirectories that contain device files are not listed in the “/etc/aide.conf” file, or if a file integrity tool is not used to check for unauthorized file modifications, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Device files and directories must only be writable by users with a system account or as configured by the vendor.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>System device files in directories that are world writable could be modified, removed, or used by an unprivileged user to control system hardware.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the device directories and subdirectories to “0755” with the following command:
# chmod 0755 <directory>

check.check-content:
Verify that all device files on the system are in directories that are not world-writable.
Find all world-writable device files existing anywhere on the system.
# find / -perm -2 -a \( -type b -o -type c \) > devicelist
Check the permissions on the directories and subdirectories containing device files.
If any of the directories or subdirectories are world-writable, excepting device files specifically intended to be world-writable such as “/dev/null”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Audio devices must have mode 0660 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Audio and video devices that are globally accessible have proven to be another security hazard. There is software that can activate system microphones and video devices connected to user workstations and/or X terminals. Once the microphone has been activated, it is possible to eavesdrop on otherwise private conversations without the victim being aware of it. This action effectively changes the user's microphone into a bugging device.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the audio device files to “0660” with the following command:
# chmod 0660 <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all audio device drivers on the system have a mode of “0660” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the audio devices on the system with the following command:
# ls -lL /dev/audio* /dev/snd/* /dev/snd crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 2 Jun 28 16:13 controlC0 crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 4 Jun 28 16:14 pcmC0D0c crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 3 Jun 28 16:34 pcmC0D0p crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 5 Jun 28 16:13 pcmC0D1c crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 1 Jun 28 16:13 seq crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 33 Jun 28 16:13 timer
If the mode of audio devices are more permissive than “0660”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Audio devices must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Audio and video devices globally accessible have proven to be another security hazard. There is software that can activate system microphones and video devices connected to user workstations and/or X terminals. Once the microphone has been activated, it is possible to eavesdrop on otherwise private conversations without the victim being aware of it. This action effectively changes the user's microphone into a bugging device.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of the audio device files to root with the following command:
# chown root <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all audio device drivers on the system are owned by root.
