Check the owner of the audio devices on the system with the following command:
# ls -lL /dev/audio* /dev/snd/* /dev/snd crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 2 Jun 28 16:13 controlC0 crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 4 Jun 28 16:14 pcmC0D0c crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 3 Jun 28 16:34 pcmC0D0p crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 5 Jun 28 16:13 pcmC0D1c crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 1 Jun 28 16:13 seq crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 33 Jun 28 16:13 timer
If the owner of audio devices is not root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Audio devices must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or audio.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Without privileged group owners, audio devices will be vulnerable to being used as eaves-dropping devices by malicious users or intruders to possibly listen to conversations containing sensitive information.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of the audio device files to audio with the following command:
# chgrp audio <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all audio device drivers on the system are group owned by root, bin, sys, or audio.
Check the group owner of the audio devices on the system with the following command:
# ls -lL /dev/audio* /dev/snd/* /dev/snd crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 2 Jun 28 16:13 controlC0 crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 4 Jun 28 16:14 pcmC0D0c crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 3 Jun 28 16:34 pcmC0D0p crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 5 Jun 28 16:13 pcmC0D1c crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 1 Jun 28 16:13 seq crw-rw----+ 1 root audio 116, 33 Jun 28 16:13 timer
If the owner of audio devices is not root, bin, sys, or audio, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must be checked weekly for unauthorized setuid files as well as unauthorized modification to authorized setuid files.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Files with the setuid bit set will allow anyone running these files to be temporarily assigned the UID of the file. While many system files depend on these attributes for proper operation, security problems can result if setuid is assigned to programs allowing reading and writing of files, or shell escapes.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to notify designated personnel if files with the setuid bit set are changed in an unauthorized manner.
The file integrity application must be configured to perform two actions:
Execute on the system with a defined frequency (daily or weekly).
Notify specified personnel of the results of the application execution.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system notifies designated personnel if files with the setuid bit set are changed in an unauthorized manner.
Note: If RHEL7-040080 has a status of Open this requirement will have a status of Open.
Note: A file integrity tool other than aide may be used, but the tool must be executed and notify specified individuals via email or an alert.
Check for the presence of a cron job running daily on the system that executes aide daily or weekly to scan for changes to files with the setuid bit set. The frequency that the file integrity tool is executed on the system may be done daily or weekly. The commands used in the example will use a weekly occurrence.
Check the “/etc/cron.weekly” subdirectory for a crontab file controlling the execution of the file integrity application. For example, if aide is installed on the system use the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/cron.weekly | grep aide -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 32 Jul 1 2011 aide
Aide does not have a configuration that will send a notification, so the cron job uses the mail application on the system to email the results of the file integrity run.
# more /etc/cron.weekly/aide 0 0 * * * /usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily AIDE integrity check run" root@sysname.mil
If the file integrity application is not executed on the system with the required frequency, if the file integrity application does not notify designated personnel of changes, or if “GEN002380” has a status of “Open”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Files systems that contain user home directories, are being imported via Network File System (NFS), or are used with removable media must be mounted to prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The "nosetuid" mount option causes the system to not execute setuid and setgid files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved setuid and setguid files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the “/etc/fstab” to use the “nosetuid” option on file systems that contain user home directories, are being exported via NFS, or are associated with removable media.

check.check-content:
Verify that file systems that contain user home directories, are being exported, or are used for removable media are mounted with the “nosetuid” option.
Check the file systems that are mounted at boot time with the following command:
# more /etc/fstab UUID=2bc871e4-e2a3-4f29-9ece-3be60c835222 /mnt/cdrom udf,iso9660 noauto,owner,ro 0 0 UUID=e06097bb-cfcd-437b-9e4d-a691f5662a7d /store nfs rw, nosetuid 0 0 UUID=a411dc99-f2a1-4c87-9e05-184977be8539 /home ext4 rw,relatime,discard,data=ordered 0 2
Find the file system(s) that contain the user home directories with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,7 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj thomasr /home/thomasr
If a file system found in “/etc/fstab” refers to NFS, removable media, or the user home directory file system, and does not have the “nosetuid” option, this is a finding.
Note: If a separate file system has not been created for the user home directories (user home directories are mounted under /) this is not a finding as the “nosetuid” option cannot be used on the “/file” system.

Rule.title: The system must be checked weekly for unauthorized setgid files as well as unauthorized modification to authorized setgid files.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Files with the setgid bit set will allow anyone running these files to be temporarily assigned the group id of the file. While many system files depend on these attributes for proper operation, security problems can result if setgid is assigned to programs allowing reading and writing of files, or shell escapes.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to notify designated personnel if files with the setgid bit set are changed in an unauthorized manner.
The file integrity application must be configured to perform two actions:
Execute on the system with a defined frequency (daily or weekly).
Notify specified personnel of the results of the application execution.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system notifies designated personnel if files with the setgid bit set are changed in an unauthorized manner.
Note: RHEL7-040080 has a status of Open this requirement will have a status of Open.
Note: A file integrity tool other than aide may be used, but the tool must be executed and notify specified individuals via email or an alert.
Check for the presence of a cron job running daily on the system that executes aide daily or weekly to scan for changes to files with the setgid bit set. The frequency that the file integrity tool is executed on the system may be done daily or weekly. The commands used in the example will use a weekly occurrence.
Check the /etc/cron.weekly subdirectory for a crontab file controlling the execution of the file integrity application. For example, if aide is installed on the system use the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/cron.weekly | grep aide -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 32 Jul 1 2011 aide
Aide does not have a configuration that will send a notification, so the cron job uses the mail application on the system to email the results of the file integrity run.
# more /etc/cron.weekly/aide 0 0 * * * /usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily AIDE integrity check run" root@sysname.mil
If the file integrity application is not executed on the system with the required frequency, if the file integrity application does not notify designated personnel of changes, or if “GEN002440” has a status of “Open”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All public directories must be owned by root or an application account.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>If a public directory has the sticky bit set and is not owned by a privileged UID, unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.
The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of the world writable directories to root with the following command:
# chown root <directory>

check.check-content:
Verify that all world writable directories are owned by root or an application account.
Check the system for world writable directories with the following command:
# find / -perm -002 -type d -exec ls -lLd {} \; drwxrwxrwt. 2 root root 40 Aug 26 13:07 /dev/mqueue drwxrwxrwt. 2 root root 220 Aug 26 13:23 /dev/shm drwxrwxrwt. 14 root root 4096 Aug 26 13:29 /tmp
If any world writable directories are not owned by root or an application associated with the directory, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All public directories must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>If a public directory has the sticky bit set and is not group-owned by a privileged Group Identifier (GID), unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.
The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group of the world writable directories to root with the following command:
# chgrp root <directory>

check.check-content:
Verify that all world writable directories are group owned by root, sys, bin or an application group.
Check the system for world writable directories with the following command:
# find / -perm -002 -type d -exec ls -lLd {} \; drwxrwxrwt. 2 root root 40 Aug 26 13:07 /dev/mqueue drwxrwxrwt. 2 root root 220 Aug 26 13:23 /dev/shm drwxrwxrwt. 14 root root 4096 Aug 26 13:29 /tmp
If any world writable directories are not owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group associated with the directory, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The default umask must be set to 077 for all existing accounts.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The umask controls the default access mode assigned to newly created files. An umask of 077 limits new files to mode 700 or less permissive. Although umask can be represented as a 4-digit number, the first digit representing special access modes is typically ignored or required to be 0. This requirement applies to the globally configured system defaults and the user defaults for each account on the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Remove the umask statement from all interactive users’ initialization files. If the account is for an application the requirement for a umask less restrictive than "077" can be documented with the ISSM, but the user agreement for access to the account must specify that the user must log into their account first and then switch user to the application account with the correct option to gain the accounts environment variables.

check.check-content:
Verify that the default umask for all interactive users if “077”.
Identify the locations of all user home directories by looking at the “/etc/passwd” file.
Check all local initialization files for interactive users with the following command:
Note: The example is for a system that is configured to create users home directories in the /home directory.
# grep –i umask /home/*/.*
If any local initialization files are found to have a umask statement that has a value less restrictive than “077”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Unnecessary default system accounts must be removed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Default system accounts created at install time but never utilized by the system may inadvertently be configured for interactive logon. Vendor accounts and software may contain accounts that provide unauthorized access to the system. All accounts that are not used to support the system and application operation must be removed from the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Remove unnecessary default accounts from the system by using the account management tool or manually editing the “/etc/password” and “/etc/shadow” files.

check.check-content:
Verify that unnecessary default system accounts have been removed.
Check the accounts that are on the system with the following command:
# more /etc/passwd root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash bin:x:1:1:bin:/bin:/sbin/nologin daemon:x:2:2:daemon:/sbin:/sbin/nologin adm:x:3:4:adm:/var/adm:/sbin/nologin lp:x:4:7:lp:/var/spool/lpd:/sbin/nologin sync:x:5:0:sync:/sbin:/bin/sync
If the accounts sync, shutdown, halt, games, or ftp exist in the “/etc/passwd” file, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The audit system must be configured to audit files and programs deleted by users.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the operating system to generate audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to delete files occur.
Add the following rules to “/etc/audit/audit.rules”:
-a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/rm -F perm=x -F auid>=500 -F auid!=4294967295 –k -F subj=unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023 privileged-priv_change
The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.

check.check-content:
Verify the operating system generates audit records when successful/unsuccessful attempts to delete files occur.
Check the file system rules in /etc/audit/audit.rules with the following commands:
# auditctl -l | grep syscall | grep unlink | grep -v unlinkat
# grep –i /usr/sbin/rm /etc/audit/audit.rules
-a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/rm -F perm=x -F auid>=500 -F auid!=4294967295 -F subj=unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023 -k privileged-priv_change
If the command does not return the rule for “/usr/sbin/rm”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Unauthorized use of the at capabilities must not be permitted.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The at facility allows users to execute recurring jobs on a regular and unattended basis. The "at.allow" file designates accounts allowed to enter and execute jobs using the at facility. If the "at.allow" file is not present, users listed in the "at.deny" file are not allowed to use the at facility. Improper configuration of at may open the facility up for abuse by system intruders and malicious users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the "at.allow" and "at.deny" files do not exist create them with the following commands:
# touch /etc/at.allow # chown root:root /etc/at.allow # chmod 0600 /etc/at.allow
Once the files are created modify the "at.allow" file to contain the users allowed to use at jobs, and modify the "at.deny" to contain the users not allowed to use at jobs (typically the default service accounts on the system).

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/at.allow” and/or “/etc/at.deny” files exist and are populated.
Check for the existence and size of the “/etc/at.allow” and “/etc/at.deny” files with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/at.allow -rw------- 1 root root 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/at.allow
# ls –al /etc/at.deny ls: cannot access /etc/at.deny: No such file or directory
If both the “/etc/at.allow” and “/etc/at.deny” files do not exist or both are empty, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Unauthorized use of the cron capabilities must not be permitted.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The cron facility allows users to execute recurring jobs on a regular and unattended basis. The "cron.allow" file designates accounts allowed to enter and execute jobs using the cron facility. If the "cron.allow" file is not present, users listed in the "cron.deny" file are not allowed to use the cron facility. Improper configuration of cron may open the facility up for abuse by system intruders and malicious users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the "cron.allow" and "cron.deny" files do not exist create them with the following commands:
# touch /etc/cron.allow # chown root:root /etc/cron.allow # chmod 0600 /etc/cron.allow
Once the files are created modify the "cron.allow" file to contain the users allowed to use cron jobs, and modify the "cron.deny" to contain the users not allowed to use corn jobs (typically the default service accounts on the system).

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/cron.allow” and/or “/etc/cron.deny” files exist and are populated.
Check for the existence and size of the “/etc/cron.allow” and “/etc/cron.deny” files with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/cron.allow -rw------- 1 root root 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/cron.allow
# ls –al /etc/cron.deny ls: cannot access /etc/cron.deny: No such file or directory
If both the “/etc/cron.allow” and “/etc/cron.deny” files do not exist or both are empty, this is a finding..

Rule.title: The cron.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A readable and/or writable "cron.allow" file by users other than root could allow potential intruders and malicious users to use the file contents to help discern information, such as who is allowed to execute cron programs, which could be harmful to overall system and network security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the “/etc/cron.allow” file to with the following command:
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.allow

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/cron.allow” has a mod of “0600” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the /etc/cron.allow file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/cron.allow -rw------- 1 root crontab 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/cron.allow
If the “/etc/cron.alllow” file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Cron must not execute group-writable or world-writable programs.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If cron executes group-writable or world-writable programs, there is a possibility that unauthorized users could manipulate the programs with malicious intent. This could compromise system and network security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the programs executed by cron to with the following command:
# chmod 0755 <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that cron does not execute group-writable or world-writable programs.
To find relevant group and world writable files use the following command once for each local partition [PART]:
# find [PART] -xdev -perm -022 -type f -exec ls -ld {} \; | more
For all files listed check for their presence in the system run control scripts with the following commands:
# grep <file> /etc/crontab # grep <file> /etc/cron.d/* # grep <file> /var/spool/cron/*
If any system run control scripts are found to reference group or world writable files, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Crontabs must be owned by root or the crontab creator.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>To protect prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be owned by root or the user account that created the crontab.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the ownership of the system crontabs to root with the following commands:
# chown root /etc/crontab # chown root /etc/cron.d/*
Set the ownership of user's crontabs to the user of the crontab with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the “jonesj” user.
# chown jonesj /var/spool/cron/jonesj

check.check-content:
Verify that all crontabs on the system are owned by root or the user that has created a crontab.
Check the owner of the system crontabs with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/crontab -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 137 Mar 27 2014 /etc/crontab
# ls –al /etc/cron.d/* -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2443 Nov 3 13:45 centreon -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2576 Nov 3 13:45 centstorage
If the “/etc/crontab” file and all of the files under “/etc/cron.d” are not owned by root this is a finding.
Check the owner of all crontab files under “/var/spool/cron/” with the following command:
# ls –al /var/spool/cron/* -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj users 2443 Nov 3 13:45 smithj -rw-r--r-- 1 throckw sa 2576 Nov 3 13:45 throckw
If the crontab for a user is not owned by that user, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Crontab files must be group-owned by root, cron, or the crontab creators primary group.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>To protect prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must have a group owner by root or the user group that created the crontab.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group ownership of the system crontabs to root with the following commands:
# chgrp root /etc/crontab # chgrp root /etc/cron.d/*
Set the ownership of user’s crontabs to the user of the crontab with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the “jonesj” user, which has a primary group of users.
# chgrp users /var/spool/cron/jonesj

check.check-content:
Verify that all crontabs on the system are group owned by root or the user that has created a crontab.
Check the group owner of the system crontabs with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/crontab -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 137 Mar 27 2014 /etc/crontab
# ls –al /etc/cron.d/* -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2443 Nov 3 13:45 centreon -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2576 Nov 3 13:45 centstorage
If the “/etc/crontab” file and all of the files under “/etc/cron.d” are not group owned by root this is a finding.
Check the group owner of all crontab files under “/var/spool/cron/” with the following command:
# ls –al /var/spool/cron/* -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj users 2443 Nov 3 13:45 smithj -rw-r--r-- 1 throckw sa 2576 Nov 3 13:45 throckw
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3,4 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" smithj /home/smithj 250
#grep 250 /etc/group users:x:250:smithj,jonesj,jacksons
Note: This may miss interactive users that have been assigned a privileged UID. Evidence of interactive use may be obtained from a number of log files to contain system logon information.
If the crontab for a user is not group owned by that users’ primary group, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Cron and crontab directories must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>To protect malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must have a mode of 0755 or less permissive.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the system crontabs to “0755” with the following commands:
# chmod 0755 /etc/crontab # chmod 0755/etc/cron.d/*
Set the mode of users’ crontabs to “0755” with the following command:
Note: The example will be for the “jonesj” user, which has a primary group of users.
# chmod 0755 /var/spool/cron/jonesj

check.check-content:
Verify that all crontabs on the system have a mode of “0755” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the system crontabs with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/crontab -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 137 Mar 27 2014 /etc/crontab
# ls –al /etc/cron.d/* -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2443 Nov 3 13:45 centreon -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 2576 Nov 3 13:45 centstorage
If the “/etc/crontab” file and all of the files under “/etc/cron.d” do not have a mode of “0755” or less permissive, this is a finding.
Check the mode of all crontab files under /var/spool/cron/ with the following command:
# ls –al /var/spool/cron/* -rw-r--r-- 1 smithj users 2443 Nov 3 13:45 smithj -rw-r--r-- 1 throckw sa 2576 Nov 3 13:45 throckw
If the crontab files under “/var/spool/cron” do not have a mode of “0755” or less permissive, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Cron and crontab directories must be owned by root or bin.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Incorrect ownership of the cron or crontab directories could permit unauthorized users the ability to alter cron jobs and run automated jobs as privileged users. Failure to give ownership of cron or crontab directories to root or to bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the ownership of the system crontabs to root with the following commands:
# chown root /etc/crontab # chown root /etc/cron.d/ # chown root /var/spool/cron

check.check-content:
Verify that all crontab directories on the system are owned by root or bin.
Check the owner of the crontab directories with the following commands:
# ls –ald /etc/crontab -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 137 Mar 27 2014 /etc/crontab
# ls –ald /etc/cron.d/ -rw-r-d-r-- 1 root root 2443 Nov 3 13:45 /etc/cron.d
# ls –ald /var/spool/cron/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root users 2443 Nov 3 13:45 /var/spool/cron
If the crontab directories are not owned by root or bin, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Cron and crontab directories must be group-owned by root, sys, bin or cron.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>To protect the integrity of scheduled system jobs and to prevent malicious modification to these jobs, crontab files must be secured. Failure to give group-ownership of cron or crontab directories to a system group provides the designated group and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the ownership of the system crontabs to root with the following commands:
# chgrp root /etc/crontab # chgrp root /etc/cron.d/ # chgrp root /var/spool/cron

check.check-content:
Verify that all crontab directories on the system are group owned by root, bin, sys, or cron.
Check the group owner of the crontab directories with the following commands:
# ls –ald /etc/crontab -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 137 Mar 27 2014 /etc/crontab
# ls –ald /etc/cron.d/ -rw-r-d-r-- 1 root root 2443 Nov 3 13:45 /etc/cron.d
# ls –ald /var/spool/cron/ -rw-r--r-- 1 root bin 2443 Nov 3 13:45 /var/spool/cron
If the system crontab directories are not group owned by root, bin, sys, or cron, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Cron logging must be implemented.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Cron logging can be used to trace the successful or unsuccessful execution of cron jobs. It can also be used to spot intrusions into the use of the cron facility by unauthorized and malicious users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure rsyslog to log all cron messages by adding or updating the following line to /etc/rsyslog.conf: cron.* /var/log/cron.log
Note: the line must be added before the following entry if it exists in /etc/rsyslog.conf: *.* ~ # discards everything

check.check-content:
Verify that rsyslog is configured to log cron events.
Check the configuration of /etc/rsyslog.conf for the cron facility with the following command:
Note: if another logging package is used substitute the utility configuration file for /etc/rsyslog.conf.
# more cron /etc/rsyslog.conf cron.* /var/log/cron.log
If the command does not return a response, check for cron logging all facilities by inspecting the /etc/rsyslog.conf file:
# more /etc/rsyslog.conf
Look for the following entry:
*.* /var/log/messages
If rsyslog is not logging messages for the cron facility or all facilities, this is a finding.
If the entry is in the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file but is after the entry: *.*', this is a finding.

Rule.title: The cronlog file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Cron logs contain reports of scheduled system activities and must be protected from unauthorized manipulation or deletion.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the cron log file to with the following command:
Note: The example uses “/var/log/cron.log” as the cron log file.
# chmod 0600 /var/log/cron.log

check.check-content:
Verify that the log file generated by rsyslog for cron messages has a mode of “0600” or less permissive.
Check the configuration of “/etc/rsyslog.conf” for the location of the file cron messages with the following command:
Note: if another logging package is used substitute the utility configuration file for “/etc/rsyslog.conf”.
# grep cron /etc/rsyslog.conf cron.* /var/log/cron.log
If the command does not return a response, check for cron logging all facilities with the following command:
# grep ‘*.*’ /etc/rsyslog.conf *.* /var/log/messages
Check the mode of indicated log file with the following command:
# ls –al /var/log/cron.log -rw------- 1 root root 211 May 17 2015 /var/log/cron.log
If the log file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The cron.deny file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If file permissions for "cron.deny" are more permissive than 0600, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the “/etc/cron.deny” file to “0600” with the following command:
# chmod 0600 /etc/cron.deny

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/cron.deny” file has a mode of “0600” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the /etc/cron.deny file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/deny.deny -rw------- 1 root root 12 Mar 6 2015 /etc/cron.deny
If the “/etc/cron.deny” file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The cron.allow file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the owner of the "cron.allow" file is not set to root the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or to edit sensitive information.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/cron.allow” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/cron.allow

check.check-content:
Verify that the "cron.allow" file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the "cron.allow" file with the following command:
# l s –al /etc/cron.allow -rw------- 1 root root 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/cron.allow
If the “cron.allow” has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The cron.allow file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the group-owner of the “cron.allow” file is not set to root sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/cron.allow” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/cron.allow

check.check-content:
Verify that the “cron.allow” file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “cron.allow” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/cron.allow -rw------- 1 root root 6 Mar 5 2011 /etc/cron.allow
If the “cron.allow” has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The cron.deny file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the owner of the “cron.deny” file is not set to root sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/cron.deny” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/cron.deny

check.check-content:
Verify the “cron.deny” file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “cron.deny” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/cron.deny -rw------- 1 root crontab 12 Mar 6 2015 /etc/cron.deny
If the “cron.deny” has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The cron.deny file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the group-owner of the “cron.deny” file is not set to root, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/cron.deny” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/cron.deny

check.check-content:
Verify that the “cron.deny” file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “cron.deny” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/cron.deny -rw------- 1 root crontab 12 Mar 6 2015 /etc/cron.deny
If the “cron.deny” has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Kernel core dumps must be disabled unless needed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Kernel core dumps may contain the full contents of system memory at the time of the crash. Kernel core dumps may consume a considerable amount of disk space and may result in denial of service by exhausting the available space on the target file system partition.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If kernel core dumps are not required disable the “kdump” service with the following command:
# systemctl disable kdump.service
If kernel core dumps are required document the need with the ISSM.

check.check-content:
Verify that kernel core dumps are disabled unless needed.
Check the status of the “kdump” service with the following command:
# systemctl status kdump.service kdump.service - Crash recovery kernel arming Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/kdump.service; enabled) Active: active (exited) since Wed 2015-08-26 13:08:09 EDT; 43min ago Main PID: 1130 (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS) kernel arming.
If the “kdump” service is active ask the system administrator if the use of the service is required and documented with the ISSM.
If the service is active and is not documented, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not forward IPv4 source-routed packets.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv4 packets with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not accept IPv4 source-routed packets.
Check the value of the accept source route variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route=0
If the returned line does not have a value of “0”, a line is not returned, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: TCP backlog queue sizes must be set appropriately.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>To provide additional mitigation to TCP Denial of Service attacks, the TCP backlog queue sizes and maximum number of allowed connections must be set higher than the kernel defaults.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the value of the TCP backlog queue to “1280” with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog=1280

check.check-content:
Verify that the value of the TCP backlog queue is at least “1280” or greater.
Check the value of the TCP backlog queue variable with the following command
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog=1280
If the returned line does not have a value of “1280” or greater, a line is not returned, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not process IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp requests.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages can be used or a number of malicious activities to include host detection, OS fingerprinting, and covert channels.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
The timestamp-reply and timestamp-request rules do not come by default in the firewalld package and must be created in “/etc/firewalld/icmptypes”.
Create timestamp-request.xml as follows:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <icmptype> <short>Timestamp Request</short> <description>This message is used for time synchronization.</description> <destination ipv4="yes"/> <destination ipv6="yes"/> </icmptype>
Create timestamp-reply.xml as follows:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <icmptype> <short>Timestamp Reply</short> <description>This message is used to reply to a timestamp message.</description> <destination ipv4="yes"/> <destination ipv6="yes"/> </icmptype>
Once the files are created they must be validated with the following commands:
# xmllint --schema /usr/lib/firewalld/xmlschema/icmptype.xsd timestamp-request.xml timestamp-request.xml validates # xmllint --noout --schema /usr/lib/firewalld/xmlschema/icmptype.xsd timestamp-reply.xml timestamp-reply.xml validates
Reload the firewall with the following command:
# firewall-cmd --reload
Add the rules to the firewalld rules with the following commands:
# firewall-cmd --add-icmp-block=timestamp-request # firewall-cmd --add-icmp-block=timestamp-reply

check.check-content:
Verify that Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp requests are blocked by the firewall.
Check that icmp timestamp replies and requests are blocked by firewalld with the following command:
# firewall-cmd --list-icmp-blocks timestamp-reply timestamp-request
If the command does not return timestamp-reply and timestamp-request, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not respond to IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Responding to broadcast (ICMP) echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not respond to IPv4 ICMP echo requests sent to broadcast addresses with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol v4 (ICMPv4) echoes sent to a broadcast address.
Check the value of the icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1
If the returned line does not have a value of “1”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) timestamp requests sent to a broadcast address.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Responding to broadcast ICMP timestamp requests facilitates network mapping, and provides a vector for amplification attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not respond to ICMP timestamp requests sent to broadcast addresses with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol v4 (ICMPv4) timestamp requests sent to a broadcast address.
Check the value of the icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1
If the returned line does not have a value of “1”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Proxy Address Resolution Protocol (Proxy ARP) must not be enabled on the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Proxy ARP allows a system to respond to ARP requests on one interface on behalf of hosts connected to another interface. If this function is enabled when not required, addressing information may be leaked between the attached network segments.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to disable Proxy Address Resolution Protocol (Proxy ARP) with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.proxy_arp=0

check.check-content:
Verify that Proxy Address Resolution Protocol (Proxy ARP) is not enabled on the system.
Check the value of the “proxy_arp” variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv4.conf.default.proxy_arp net.ipv4.conf.default.proxy_arp=0
If net.ipv4.conf.default.proxy_arp does not have a value of “0”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must ignore IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to ignore IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages with the following commands:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0 # /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects=0

check.check-content:
Verify that the system ignores IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
Check the value of the “accept_redirects” variables with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep 'net.ipv4.conf.*.accept_redirects' net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects=0 net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects=0
If both of the returned line does not have a value of “0”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not send IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table possibly revealing portions of the network topology.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not send IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages with the following commands:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects=0 # /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not send IPv4 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
Check the value of the "send_redirects" variables with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -a | grep 'net.ipv4.conf.*.send_redirects' net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects=0 net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0
If both of the returned lines do not have a value of “0”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must be configured to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A TCP SYN flood attack can cause Denial of Service by filling a system's TCP connection table with connections in the SYN_RCVD state. Syncookies are a mechanism used to only track a connection when a subsequent ACK is received, verifying the initiator is attempting a valid connection and is not a flood source. This technique does not operate in a fully standards-compliant manner, but is only activated when a flood condition is detected, and allows defense of the system while continuing to service valid requests.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to use TCP syncookies with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies=1

check.check-content:
Verify the system is configured to use TCP syncookies when experiencing a TCP SYN flood.
Check the value of the tcp_syncookies variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -a net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies=1
If the returned line does not have a value of “1”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not be configured for network bridging.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Some systems have the ability to bridge or switch frames (link-layer forwarding) between multiple interfaces. This can be useful in a variety of situations but, if enabled when not needed, has the potential to bypass network partitioning and security.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove any unapproved bridges from the system with the following command:
# nmcli con del type bridge br*

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not have a bridge configured unless the system is approved to be used as a bridge.
Check for the existence of a bridge configuration on the system with the following command:
# nmcli con show | grep br NAME UUID TYPE DEVICE bridge-br0 79cf6a3e-0310-4a78-b759-bda1cc3eef8d bridge br0
If any entries have a type of "bridge" this is a finding unless the bridge configuration has been documented with the ISSO.

Rule.title: A separate file system must be used for user home directories (such as /home or an equivalent).
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Migrate the /home (or equivalent) path onto a separate file system.

check.check-content:
Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created for interactive user home directories.
Check the home directory assignment for all non-privileged users on the system with the following command:
# cut -d: -f 1,3 /etc/passwd | egrep ":[1-4][0-9]{2}$|:[0-9]{1,2}$" adamsj /home/adamsj jacksonm /home/jacksonm smithj /home/smithj
The output of the command will give the directory/partition that contains the home directories for the interactive users on the system (in this example /home). It is possible that there may be multiple directories/partitions for interactive users; if so, repeat the following section for all applicable directories/partitions.
Check that a file system/partition has been created for the interactive users with the following command:
Note: The partition of /home is used in the example.
# grep /home /etc/fstab UUID=333ada18 /home ext4 noatime,nobarrier,nodev 1 2
If a separate entry for the file system/partition that contains the interactive users' home directories does not exist, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must use a separate file system for /var.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Migrate the /var path onto a separate file system.

check.check-content:
Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created /var.
Check that a file system/partition has been created for /var with the following command:
# grep /var /etc/fstab UUID=c274f65f /var ext4 noatime,nobarrier 1 2
If a separate entry for /var is not in use this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must use a separate file system for the system audit data path.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Migrate the system audit data path onto a separate file system.

check.check-content:
Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created the system audit data path.
Check that a file system/partition has been created for the system audit data path with the following command:
#grep /var/log/audit /etc/fstab UUID=3645951a /var/log/audit ext4 defaults 1 2
If a separate entry for /var/log/audit does not exist ask the SA if the system audit logs are being written to a different file system/partition on the system, then grep for that file system/partition.
If a separate file system/partition does not exist for the system audit data path, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Migrate the “/tmp” path onto a separate file system.

check.check-content:
Verify that a separate file system/partition has been created for “/tmp”.
Check that a file system/partition has been created for “/tmp” with the following command:
# grep /tmp /etc/fstab UUID=7835718b /tmp ext4 nodev,nosetuid,noexec 1 2
If a separate entry for “/tmp” is not in use, this is a finding.

Rule.title: All file systems must employ journaling or another mechanism to ensure file system consistency.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>File system journaling, or logging, can allow reconstruction of file system data after a system crash, preserving the integrity of data that may have otherwise been lost. Journaling file systems typically do not require consistency checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability. Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency also satisfying this requirement.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Migrate the file system to a type that supports journaling, or turn on journaling if it is turned off on a file system that already supports it.

check.check-content:
Verify that the root file system must employ journaling or another mechanism ensuring file system consistency.
Check the file system type for the root file system/partition with the following command:
# mount /dev/sda1 on / type xfs (rw,relatime,attr2,inode64,noquota)
Note: JFS, VXFS, HFS, XFS, reiserfs, EXT3, and EXT4 all use journaling and will not be a finding.
Note: The ZFS file system uses other mechanisms to provide for file system consistency and will not be a finding.
For other file systems types, if the root file system does not have the logging option, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The xinetd service must be removed if no network services utilizing it is enabled.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Unnecessary services must be removed to decrease the attack surface of the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the “xinetd” service is not required remove it from the system with the following command:
# yum remove xinetd

check.check-content:
Verify the “xinetd” service is not installed if it is unnecessary.
Check to see if the “xinetd” package is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep xinet xinetd-2.3.15-12.el7.rpm
If the package is installed check to see if any services require the xinetd daemon with the following command:
# more /etc/xinetd.d/* | grep disable disable = yes disable = yes disable = no
If all of the services are disabled, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The xinetd configuration files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The Internet service daemon configuration files must be protected as malicious modification could cause Denial of Service or increase the attack surface of the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the files “/etc/xinetd.d” directory to “0640” with the following command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/xinetd.d/*

check.check-content:
Verify that the configuration files under “/etc/xinet.d” have a mode of “0640” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the files under /etc/xinetd.d with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/xinetd.d -rw-------. 1 root root 1157 Jun 9 2014 chargen-dgram -rw-------. 1 root root 1159 Jun 9 2014 chargen-stream -rw-------. 1 root root 1157 Jun 9 2014 daytime-dgram
If any of the files under “/etc/xinetd.d” has a mode more permissive than “0640”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The xinetd.d directory must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The Internet service daemon configuration files must be protected as malicious modification could cause Denial of Service or increase the attack surface of the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the “/etc/xinetd.d” directory to “0755” with the following command:
# chmod 0755 /etc/xinetd.d

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/xinet.d” directory has a mode of “0755” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/xinetd.d” directory with the following command:
# ls –ald /etc/xinetd.d -rwxr-xr-x 12 root root 132 Mar 6 2015 /etc/xinetd.d
If the “/etc/xinetd.d” directory has a mode more permissive than “0755”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The services file must be owned by root or bin.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Failure to give ownership of the /etc/services file to root or bin provides the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration possibly weakening the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner of the “/etc/services” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/services

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/services” file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the /etc/services with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/services -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 4 Mar 12 14:21 services
If the “/etc/services” file has an owner other than root or bin, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The services file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Failure to give ownership of system configuration files to root or a system group provides unauthorized users with the potential to change the system configuration possibly weakening the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner of the “/etc/services” to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/services

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/services” file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/services” with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/services -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 4 Mar 12 14:21 services
If the “/etc/services” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The services file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The services file is critical to the proper operation of network services and must be protected from unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification could result in the failure of network services.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the “/etc/services” to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/services

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/services” file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode owner of the “/etc/services” with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/services -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 4 Mar 12 14:21 services
If the “/etc/services” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: xinetd logging/tracing must be enabled via rsyslog.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>xinetd logging and tracing allows the system administrators to observe the IP addresses connecting to their machines and what network services are being sought. This provides valuable information when trying to find the source of malicious traffic.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure “rsyslog” to capture log messages from the daemon facility by adding the following line after the templates section in the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file:
daemon.* /var/log/messages

check.check-content:
Verify “xinetd” logging/tracing is enabled to be captured by “rsyslog”.
Note: It is possible that “/etc/rsyslog.conf” may be configured to listen on specific ports for specific services and capture the logs individually.
Check to see if the “xinetd” package is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep xinet xinetd-2.3.15-12.el7.rpm
If the package is installed check the configuration of rsyslogd with the following command:
# grep daemon /etc/rsyslog.conf # grep ‘*.*’ /etc/rsyslog.conf *.* @@1.2.3.4:2010;SyslFormat
If neither of the commands returns any output, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The rpcbind service must not be running unless needed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The "rpcbind" service is used by a variety of services using Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs). The “rpcbind” service increases the attack surface of the system, and will only be used if there is an operational need.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
The “rpcbind” package cannot be removed from the system under normal circumstances due to other package dependencies so if the service is not required it may be disabled with the following command:
# yum disable rpcbind.service
If the “rpcbind” service is required, document the services that require it to be active with the ISSM.

check.check-content:
Verify the “rpcbind” service is not active unless needed.
Check the status of the “rpcbind” service with the following command:
# systemctl status rpcbind.service rpcbind.service - RPC bind service Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/rpcbind.service; static) Active: inactive (dead)
If the service is active ask the system administrator for documentation that shows which service(s) need “rpcbind”.
If there is no documentation on which services need “rpcbind”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Network analysis tools must not be installed.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Network analysis tools allow for the capture of all network traffic visible to the system. If unauthorized individuals can access these applications it may allow then to collect information such as logon IDs, passwords, and key exchanges between systems.
If the system is being used to perform a network troubleshooting function the use of these tools must be documented with the ISSM and restricted to only authorized personnel.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the network analysis tools are approved for use by the ISSM they must be documented. Remove unapproved network analysis tool packages from the system with the following commands:
# yum remove nmap-ncat # yum remove tcpdump # yum remove wireshark

check.check-content:
Verify network analysis tools are not be installed unless approved by the ISSM and documented.
Check for the presence of network analysis tools that are readily available for Red Hat 7 with the following command:
# yum list installed nmap-ncat # yum list installed tcpdump # yum list installed wireshark
If nmap, tcpdump, or wireshark are found on the system and their use has not been approved by the ISSM and documented, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Privileged accounts on the system must not utilize a web browser on the system, with the exception to access webpages used of administration of applications on the system.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a web browser flaw is exploited while being used by a privileged user, the entire system could be compromised. Specific exceptions for local service administration should be documented with the ISSO. These exceptions may include HTTPS based interfaces used for the administration of the local system, services, or attached devices.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Enforce policy requiring administrative accounts use web browsers only for local service administration.

check.check-content:
Look in the root account home directory for a “.mozilla directory”.
If a “.mozilla directory” does not exist, this is not a finding.
If a “.mozilla directory” exists, verify with the root users and the ISSO the intent of the browsing.
If the browsing is not limited to authorized local services administration, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Files executed through a mail aliases file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a file executed through a mail aliases file is not owned and writable only by root, it may be subject to unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification of files executed through aliases may allow unauthorized users to attain root privileges.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If an alias is no longer required to be executed modify the “/etc/aliases” file to remove it. If the file is still required to be executed set the owner of the files to root with the following commands:
Note: The example uses the script “newticket.php” in the “/var/www” subdirectory.
# chown root /var/www/newticket.php

check.check-content:
Verify that any files executed through mail aliases are owned by root, and reside within a directory owned and writable only by root.
Check for the presence of files being executed through an alias with the following command:
# more /etc/aliases mailer-daemon: postmaster postmaster: root nobody: root newticket: "| php -q /var/www/newticket.php"
Files being executed via an alias will point to the script or program being executed. In this example the file “newticket.php” is being executed from /var/www. To check the file and directory ownership use the following commands:
# ls –al /var/www/newticket.php -rw------- 1 root root 3369 Jan 6 2014 newticket.php
# ls –ald /var/www drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 4096 Feb 13 07:44 /var/www
If the executed file is not owned by root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Files executed through a mail aliases file must reside within a directory owned and writable only by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a file executed through a mail aliases file is not owned and writable only by root, it may be subject to unauthorized modification. Unauthorized modification of files executed through aliases may allow unauthorized users to attain root privileges.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
