Rule.fixtext:
If an alias is no longer required to be executed modify the “/etc/aliases” file to remove it. If the file is still required to be executed modify the ownership and permissions of the directory they reside in with the following commands:
Note: The example uses the script “newticket.php” in the “/var/www” subdirectory.
# chown root /var/www # chgrp root /var/www # chmod 0755 /var/www

check.check-content:
Verify that any files executed through mail aliases are owned by root, and reside within a directory owned and writable only by root.
Check for the presence of files being executed through an alias with the following command:
# more /etc/aliases mailer-daemon: postmaster postmaster: root nobody: root newticket: "| php -q /var/www/newticket.php"
Files being executed via an alias will point to the script or program being executed. In this example the file “newticket.php” is being executed from “/var/www”. To check the file and directory ownership use the following commands:
# ls –ald /var/www drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 4096 Feb 13 07:44 /var/www
If the directory in which the file resides is writable by any user other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Files executed through the mail aliases file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a file executed through a mail aliases file has permissions greater than 0600, it can be modified by an unauthorized user and may contain malicious code or instructions potentially compromising the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of files executed through mail aliases to “0600” with the following command:
Note: The example uses the script “newticket.php” in the “/var/www” subdirectory.
# chmod 0600 /var/www/newticket.php

check.check-content:
Verify that any files executed through mail aliases have a mode of “0600” or less permissive.
Check for the presence of files being executed through an alias with the following command:
# more /etc/aliases mailer-daemon: postmaster postmaster: root nobody: root newticket: "| php -q /var/www/newticket.php"
Files being executed via an alias will point to the script or program being executed. In this example the file “newticket.php” is being executed from “/var/www”. To check the mode of the file being executed use the following command:
# ls –al /var/www/newticket.php -rw------- 1 root root 3369 Jan 6 2014 newticket.php
If the executed file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system rsyslog service must log informational and more severe SMTP service messages.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If informational and more severe SMTP service messages are not logged, malicious activity on the system may go unnoticed.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Add a rule to the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file to log mail service message at the levels higher than info:
mail.*;mail.!=info /var/log/mail

check.check-content:
Verify the system “rsyslog service” logs informational and more severe SMTP service messages.
Check the configuration of rsyslog in respect to logging all messages with the following command:
# grep ‘*.*’ /etc/rsyslog.conf *.* /var/log/messages
If a rule for all facilities and all priorities being logged is not found then check for mail specific messages being logged with the following command:
# grep ‘mail.’ /etc/rsyslog.conf mail.*;mail.!=info /var/log/mail
If a rule does not exist for logging mail facilities at the info priority or higher, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SMTP service log file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) service log file is not owned by root unauthorized personnel may modify or delete the file to hide malicious activity.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner of the system rsyslog mail service log to root with the following command:
Note: The example /var/log/mail will be used.
# chown root /var/log/mail

check.check-content:
Verify the system logs the SMTP service messages.
Check the configuration of rsyslog in respect to logging all messages with the following command:
# grep ‘*.*’ /etc/rsyslog.conf *.* /var/log/messages
If a rule for all facilities and all priorities being logged is not found then check for mail specific messages being logged with the following command:
# grep ‘mail.’ /etc/rsyslog.conf mail.*;mail.!=info /var/log/mail
If a rule does not exist for logging mail facilities at the info priority or higher, this is a finding.
If a rule does exist for logging mail facility messages or all facility messages, check the owner of the file with the following command:
Note: The example used will be /var/log/mail.
# ls –al /var/log/mail -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 72332 Oct 11 2010 mail
If the log file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SMTP service log file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) service log file is more permissive than 0644 unauthorized personnel may modify or delete the file to hide malicious activity.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the mode of the system rsyslog mail service log to “0644” with the following command:
Note: The example /var/log/mail will be used.
# chmod 0644 /var/log/mail

check.check-content:
Verify the system logs the SMTP service messages.
Check the configuration of rsyslog in respect to logging all messages with the following command:
# grep ‘*.*’ /etc/rsyslog.conf *.* /var/log/messages
If a rule for all facilities and all priorities being logged is not found then check for mail specific messages being logged with the following command:
# grep ‘mail.’ /etc/rsyslog.conf mail.*;mail.!=info /var/log/mail
If a rule does not exist for logging mail facilities at the info priority or higher, this is a finding.
If a rule does exist for logging mail facility messages, or all facility messages, check the mode of the file with the following command:
Note: The example used will be /var/log/mail
# ls –al /var/log/mail -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 72332 Oct 11 2010 mail
If the log file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SMTP server must be the latest version available from operating system vendor.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The version of "postfix" or "sendmail" on the system must be current to avoid exposing vulnerabilities present in unpatched versions.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Obtain and install the newest version of the SMTP service software (“sendmail” or "postfix") from Red Hat.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SMTP server on the system is the latest version from the vendor.
Check the version of postfix on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep postfix postfix-2.6.6-6.el7.x86_64.rpm
Check for the version of "sendmail" on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep sendmail sendmail-8.14.4-9.el7.x86_64.rpm
If “postfix” is installed and is not at least version “postfix-2.6.6-6” or higher, this is a finding.
If "sendmail" is installed and is not at least version “sendmail-8.14.4-9” or higher, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must be configured to prevent unrestricted mail relaying.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If unrestricted mail relaying is permitted, unauthorized senders could use this host as a mail relay for the purpose of sending SPAM or other unauthorized activity.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If “postfix” is installed modify the “/etc/postfix/main.cf” file to restrict client connections to the local network with the following configuration line:
smtpd_client_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject
If “sendmail” is installed modify the “/etc/mail/sendmail.mc” file to bind “sendmail” to the loopback address with the following configuration line:
dnl DAEMON_OPTIONS(`Port=smtp,Addr=127.0.0.1, Name=MTA')
Then rebuild the “/etc/sendmail.cf” file with the following command:
# m4 /etc/mail/sendmail.mc > /etc/sendmail.cf

check.check-content:
Verify that the system must be configured to prevent unrestricted mail relaying.
Determine if "postfix" or "sendmail" are installed with the following commands:
# yum list installed | grep postfix postfix-2.6.6-6.el7.x86_64.rpm # yum list installed | grep sendmail
If neither are installed, this is Not Applicable.
If postfix is installed determine if it is configured to reject connections from unknown or untrusted networks with the following command:
# grep smtpd_client_restrictions /etc/postfix/main.cf smtpd_client_restrictions = permit_mynetworks, reject
If the “smtpd_client_restrictions” parameter contains any entries other than "permit_mynetworks" and "reject", this is a finding.
If “sendmail” is installed determine if it is configured to bind to only the localhost with the following command:
# grep -i "daemonportoptions" /etc/mail/sendmail.cf O DaemonPortOptions=Port=smtp,Addr=127.0.0.1, Name=MTA
If the "Addr" variable is not set to the loopback address, or the IP address of the system, this is a finding.

Rule.title: A ftp server package must not be installed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The ftp service provides an unencrypted remote access which does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session. If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised. SSH or other encrypted file transfer methods must be used in place of this service.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the "vsftpd" package from the system with the following command:
# yum remove vsftpd

check.check-content:
Verify that an ftp server has not been installed on the system.
Check to see if an ftp server has been installed with the following commands:
# yum installed list | grep vsftpd vsftpd-2.2.2-14.el7.x86_64.rpm
# yum installed list “ grep
An alternate method of determining if an ftp server is active on the server is active is to use the following command:
# netstat –a | grep 22
If “vsftpd” is installed, or if an application is listening on port 22, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The TFTP server package must not be installed if not required for operational support.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If TFTP is required for operational support (such as the transmission of router configurations) its use must be documented with the ISSM, restricted to only authorized personnel, and have access control rules established.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the TFTP package from the system with the following command:
# yum remove tftp

check.check-content:
Verify that a TFTP server has not been installed on the system.
Check to see if a TFTP server has been installed with the following command:
# yum installed list | grep tftp-server tftp-server-0.49-9.el7.x86_64.rpm
An alternate method of determining if a TFTP server is active on the server is active is to use the following commands:
# netstat –a | grep 69 # netstat –a | grep 8099
If TFTP is installed and the requirement for TFTP is not documented with the ISSM , this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the TFTP server is needed the TFTP daemon must be configured to use a dedicated unprivileged user account that is assigned a non-interactive shell.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If TFTP has a an interactive shell, it increases the likelihood someone could log on to the TFTP account and compromise the system. If the TFTP account has privileged access it elevates the severity of any compromise.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Create or modify an account for the TFTP user, ensuring that it does not have an interactive shell and has a userid greater than “500”. Configure the “/etc/xinetd.d/tftp” file to use the TFTP account.

check.check-content:
Verify the TFTP daemon is configured to use a dedicated unprivileged user account that is assigned a non-login shell.
Check to see if a TFTP server has been installed with the following commands:
#yum installed list | grep tftp tftp-0.49-9.el7.x86_64.rpm
If a TFTP server is not installed, this is Not Applicable.
If a TFTP server is installed check for the user being used by the daemon with the following command:
# grep user /etc/xinetd.d/tftp user = root
If user is set to root, this is a finding.
If the user is set to another account check to see if the userid is greater than “500” and that the account has a non-interactive shell with the following command:
Note: The example uses a user account of "tftp".
# grep tftp /etc/passwd tftp:*:510:2:Trivial FTP User:/var/tftpdir:/bin/false
If the account does not have a userid greater than “500” or is assigned an interactive shell, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the TFTP server is needed the TFTP daemon must be configured to use a dedicated home directory.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Restricting Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) to a specific directory prevents remote users from copying, transferring, or overwriting system files.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Create or modify an account for the TFTP user, ensuring that the account is assigned a home directory used only for TFTP activity.

check.check-content:
Verify that the TFTP daemon is configured to use a dedicated home directory.
Check to see if a TFTP server has been installed with the following commands:
# yum installed list | grep tftp tftp-0.49-9.el7.x86_64.rpm
If a TFTP server is not installed, this is Not Applicable.
If a TFTP server is installed check for the user being used by the daemon with the following command:
# grep user /etc/xinetd.d/tftp user = root
If user is set to root, this is a finding.
If the user is set to another account check to see if account has a dedicated home directory with the following command:
Note: The example uses a user account of "tftp".
# grep tftp /etc/passwd tftp:*:510:2:Trivial FTP User:/var/tftpdir:/bin/false
If the account does not have a home directory that is only used for TFTP activity, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the TFTP server is needed the TFTP home directory must be owned by the TFTP user account.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Restricting the Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) home directory to an unprivileged account prevents remote users from copying, transferring, or overwriting system files.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If a TFTP server is installed create an account for the TFTP user with a non-privileged userid, a user home directory, and a non-interactive shell . Create the TFTP user home directory specified in the “/etc/passwd” file, ensuring that is it owned by the user. Modify the user option in “/etc/xinetd.d/tftp” to start the tftpd daemon as the TFTP user.

check.check-content:
Verify that the dedicated home directory used by the TFTP daemon is owned by the TFTP user.
Check to see if a TFTP server has been installed with the following commands:
# yum installed list | grep tftp tftp-0.49-9.el7.x86_64.rpm
If a TFTP server is not installed, this is Not Applicable.
If a TFTP server is installed check for the user being used by the daemon with the following command:
# grep user /etc/xinetd.d/tftp user = root
If user is set to root, this is a finding.
If the user is set to another account check to see if account has a dedicated home directory with the following command:
Note: The example uses a user account of "tftp".
# grep tftp /etc/passwd tftp:*:510:2:Trivial FTP User:/var/tftpdir:/bin/false
Check to see the owner of the TFTP home directory with the following command:
# ls –ald /var/tftpdir -rwxrwxrwx 1 tftp tftp 88 Nov 18 05:21 tftpdir
If the directory is not owned by the TFTP user, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Remote X connections for interactive users must be encrypted.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Open X displays allow an attacker to capture keystrokes and to execute commands remotely.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure SSH to encrypt connections for interactive users.
Edit the appropriate “sshd_config” file to uncomment or add the line for the X11Forwarding keyword and set its value to “yes”:
X11Fowarding yes

check.check-content:
Verify that remote X connections for interactive users are be encrypted.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i x11forwarding <sshd_config file> X11Fowarding yes
If the X11Forwarding keyword is set to "no", is missing, or is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: X Windows displays must not be exported to the world.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Open X displays allow an attacker to capture keystrokes and to execute commands remotely. Many users have their X Server set to “xhost +”, permitting access to the X Server by any user from any host.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If using an xhost-type authentication the "xhost -" command can be used to remove current trusted hosts and then selectively allow only trusted hosts to connect with "xhost +" commands. A cryptographically secure authentication, such as provided by the xauth program, is always preferred.

check.check-content:
If X windows is not used on the system, this is not applicable.
Verify that the system in not exporting X windows sessions without access control.
Check the state of the X windows access control with the following command:
# xhost Access control is enabled, only authorized clients can connect.
Note: It may be necessary to define the display if the command reports it cannot open the display.
# DISPLAY=MachineName:0.0; export DISPLAY
MachineName may be replaced with an Internet Protocol Address. Repeat the "xhost" check procedure after setting the display.
If the command returns access control is disabled, this is a finding.

Rule.title: A X windows display manager must not be running unless approved.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Internet services that are not required for system or application processes must not be active to decrease the attack surface of the system. X windows has a long history of security vulnerabilities and will not be used unless approved and documented.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Document the requirement for an X Windows server with the ISSM or remove the package with the following command:
# yum remove xorg-x11-server-common

check.check-content:
Verify that if the system is using X windows that it is authorized.
Check to see if X windows is running with the following command:
# ps -ef |grep X root 507 506 0 May11 tty1 02:36:41 /usr/bin/Xorg :0 -nr -verbose -auth /var/run/gdm/auth-for-gdm-QfEeV5/database -nolisten tcp vt1
Ask the SA if use of the X window system is an operational requirement.
If the use of X windows on the system is not documented with the ISSM, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The UUCP package must not be installed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The Unix-to-Unix Copy Program/Protocol (UUCP) application is designed to assist in transferring files, executing remote commands, and sending e-mail between UNIX systems over phone lines and direct connections between systems. The UUCP utility is a primitive and arcane system with many security issues. There are alternate data transfer utilities/products that can be configured to more securely transfer data by providing for authentication as well as encryption.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the UUCP package with the following command:
# yum remove uucp

check.check-content:
Verify that the UUCP package is not installed.
Check to see if the UUCP package is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep uucp
If any UUCP package is installed, this is a finding.

Rule.title: SNMP community strings must be changed from the default.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Whether active or not, default simple network management protocol (SNMP) community strings must be changed to maintain security. If the service is running with the default authenticators, then anyone can gather data about the system and the network and use the information to potentially compromise the integrity of the system or network(s). It is highly recommended that SNMP version 3 user authentication and message encryption be used in place of the version 2 community strings.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file exists modify any lines that contain a community string of public or private to another string.

check.check-content:
Verify that a system using SNMP is not using default community strings.
Check to see if the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file exists with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf -rw------- 1 root root 52640 Mar 12 11:08 snmpd.conf
If the file does not exist, this is Not Applicable.
If the file does exist check for the default community strings with the following commands:
# grep public /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf # grep private /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf
If either of these command returns any output, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The snmpd.conf file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file to “0600’ with the following command:
# chmod 0600 /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file has a mode of “0600” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf -rw------- 1 root root 52640 Mar 12 11:08 snmpd.conf
If the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The snmpd.conf file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification. If the file is not owned by root, it may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file is owned by root. Check the owner of the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf -rw------- 1 root root 52640 Mar 12 11:08 snmpd.conf
If the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The snmpd.conf file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The snmpd.conf file contains authenticators and must be protected from unauthorized access and modification. If the file is not group-owned by a system group, it may be subject to access and modification from unauthorized users.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf -rw------- 1 root root 52640 Mar 12 11:08 snmpd.conf
If the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Management Information Base (MIB) files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The ability to modify or read the MIB file could allow a malicious user to extract configuration information about the system or network.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode MIB files on the system to “0640” with the following command:
# chmod 0640 <file>

check.check-content:
Verify that all MIB files on the system have a mode of “0640” or less permissive.
Check the permissions of all MIB files on the system with the following command:
# find / -name *.mib -exec ls -ld {} \; -rw------- 1 root root 75231 Nov 8 15:19 mmalert.mib -rw------- 1 root root 1613872 Nov 8 15:19 mmblade.mib
If any MIB file has a mode more permissive than “0640”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/rsyslog.conf file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Unauthorized users must not be allowed to access or modify the /etc/rsyslog.conf file.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file to “0640” with the following command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/rsyslog.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” has a mode of “0640” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the /etc/rsyslog.conf file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/rsyslog.conf -rw------- 1 root root 7640 Mar 4 11:08 rsyslog.conf
If the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0640”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/rsyslog.conf file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the /etc/rsyslog.conf file is not owned by root, unauthorized users could be allowed to view, edit, or delete important system messages handled by the rsyslog facility.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/rsyslog.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/rsyslog.conf -rw------- 1 root root 7640 Mar 4 11:08 rsyslog.conf
If the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/rsyslog.conf file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the group owner of /etc/rsyslog.conf is not root, unauthorized users could be permitted to view, edit, or delete important system messages handled by the rsyslog facility.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/snmp/snmpd.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/snmp/snmpd.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/rsyslog.conf -rw------- 1 root root 7640 Mar 4 11:08 rsyslog.conf
If the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must send rsyslog output to a log aggregation server.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Sending rsyslog output to another system ensures that the logs cannot be removed or modified in the event that the system is compromised or has a hardware failure.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Modify the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file to contain a configuration line to send all “rsyslog” output to a log aggregation system:
*.* @@<log aggregation system name>

check.check-content:
Verify that “rsyslog” is configured to send all messages to a log aggregation server.
Check the configuration of “rsyslog” with the following command:
# grep @ /etc/rsyslog.conf *.* @@logagg.site.mil
If there are no lines in the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file that contain the “@” or “@@” symbol(s), and the lines with the correct symbol(s) to send output to another system do not cover all “rsyslog” output, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The rsyslog daemon must not accept log messages from other servers unless the server is being used for log aggregation.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Unintentionally running a rsyslog server accepting remote messages puts the system at increased risk. Malicious rsyslog messages sent to the server could exploit vulnerabilities in the server software itself, could introduce misleading information in to the system's logs, or could fill the system's storage leading to a Denial of Service. If the system is intended to be a log aggregation server its use must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Modify the “/etc/rsyslog.conf” file to remove the “ModLoad imtcp” configuration line, or document the system as being used for log aggregation.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system is not accepting “rsyslog” messages from other systems unless it is documented as a log aggregation server.
Check the configuration of rsyslog with the following command:
# grep imtcp /etc/rsyslog.conf ModLoad imtcp
If the imtcp module is being loaded in “/etc/rsyslog.conf” ask to see the documentation for the system being used for log aggregation.
If the documentation does not exist, or does not specify the server as a log aggregation system, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>SSHv1 is an insecure implementation of the SSH protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits. Exploits of the SSH daemon could provide immediate root access to the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove all Protocol lines that reference version 1 in all sshd_config files on the system. The "Protocol" line must be as follows:
Protocol 2

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon is configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i protocol <sshd_config file> Protocol 2 #Protocol 1,2
If any protocol line other than "Protocol 2" is uncommented, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers. The only SSHv2 cipher meeting this requirement is AES.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment and modify the “Ciphers” line in all “sshd_config” files on the system to use “aes128-ctr”, “aes192-ctr”, and/or “aes256-ctr”.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon is configured to only use FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
The location of the “sshd_config” file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name 'sshd*_config'
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i ciphers <sshd_config file> Ciphers aes128-ctr,aes192-ctr,aes256-ctr,arcfour256,arcfour128,aes128-cbc,3des-cbc,blowfish-cbc,cast128-cbc,aes192-cbc,aes256-cbc,arcfour
If any ciphers other than “aes128-ctr”, “aes192-ctr”, or “aes256-ctr” are listed, the “Ciphers” keyword is missing, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to not use Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) ciphers.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment and modify the “Ciphers” line in all “sshd_config” files on the system to use “aes128-ctr”, “aes192-ctr”, and/or “aes256-ctr”.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon is configured to only use CTR ciphers.
The location of the “sshd_config” file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name 'sshd*_config'
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i ciphers <sshd_config file> Ciphers aes128-ctr,aes192-ctr,aes256-ctr,arcfour256,arcfour128,aes128-cbc,3des-cbc,blowfish-cbc,cast128-cbc,aes192-cbc,aes256-cbc,arcfour
If any ciphers other than “aes128-ctr”, “aes192-ctr”, or “aes256-ctr” are listed, the “Ciphers” keyword is missing, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use Message Authentication Codes (MACs) employing FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash algorithms.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>DoD information systems are required to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hash functions. The only SSHv2 hash algorithm meeting this requirement is SHA.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Modify the MACs line in all “sshd_config” files on the system to “usehmac-sha1” and/or “hmac-sha1-96”.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon is configured to only use Message Authentication Codes (MACs) employing FIPS 140-2 approved ciphers.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name 'sshd*_config'
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i macs <sshd_config file> MACs hmac-md5,hmac-sha1
If any ciphers other than “hmac-sha1”, “hmac-sha2-256”, or “hmac-sha2-512” are listed or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must restrict logon ability to specific users and/or groups.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Restricting SSH logons to a limited group of users, such as system administrators, prevents password-guessing and other SSH attacks from reaching system accounts and other accounts not authorized for SSH access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment and modify all of the “sshd_config” files on the system to either restrict users with the “AllowUsers” and “AllowGroups” keywords, or deny users with the “DenyUsers” and “DenyGroups” keywords.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon is configured restrict logon ability to specific users and/or groups.
The location of the “sshd_config” file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name 'sshd*_config'
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following commands:
# grep –i denyusers <sshd_config file> DenyUsers throckw
# grep –i denygroups <sshd_config file> DenyGroups users bin sys
# grep –i allowusers <sshd_config file>
# grep –i allowgroups <sshd_config file>
At least one of the four keywords must be returned and not be commented out.
If all of the keywords are missing, or all returned keywords are commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH public host key files must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If a public host key file is modified by an unauthorized user, the SSH service may be compromised.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Note: SSH public key files may be found in other directories on the system depending on the installation.
The following command will find all SSH public key files on the system:
# find / -name ‘*key.pub’
Change the mode of public host key files under “/etc/ssh” to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/ssh/*.key.pub

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH public host key files have mode “0644” or less permissive.
Note: SSH public key files may be found in other directories on the system depending on the installation.
The following command will find all SSH public key files on the system:
# find / -name '*key.pub'
Check the mode of the public host key files under /etc/ssh file with the following command:
# ls -lL /etc/ssh/*key.pub -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 618 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_dsa_key.pub -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 347 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_key.pub -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 238 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_rsa_key.pub
If any file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH private host key files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If an unauthorized user obtains the private SSH host key file, the host could be impersonated.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Note: SSH private key files may be found in other directories on the system depending on the installation.
The following command will find all SSH private key files on the system:
# find / -name '*ssh_host*key'
Change the mode of private host key files under “/etc/ssh” to “0600” with the following command:
# chmod 0600 /etc/ssh/ssh_host*key

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH private host key files have mode “0600” or less permissive.
Note: SSH private key files may be found in other directories on the system depending on the installation.
The following command will find all SSH private key files on the system:
# find / -name '*ssh_host*key'
Check the mode of the private host key files under /etc/ssh file with the following command:
# ls -lL /etc/ssh/*key -rw------- 1 root wheel 668 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_dsa_key -rw------- 1 root wheel 582 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_key -rw------- 1 root wheel 887 Nov 28 06:43 ssh_host_rsa_key
If any file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system’s GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment the “GSSAPIAuthentication” keyword in all “sshd_config” files on the system to and set the value to "no". If GSSAPI authentication is required it must be documented to include the location of the configuration file with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon does not permit GSSAPI authentication unless approved.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name 'sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i gssapiauth <sshd_config file> GSSAPIAuthentication yes
If the “GSSAPIAuthentication” keyword is missing, is set to “yes” and is not documented with the ISSO, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Kerberos authentication for SSH is often implemented using GSSAPI. If Kerberos is enabled through SSH, the SSH daemon provides a means of access to the system's Kerberos implementation. Vulnerabilities in the system's Kerberos implementation may then be subject to exploitation. To reduce the attack surface of the system, the Kerberos authentication mechanism within SSH must be disabled for systems not using this capability.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment the “KerberosAuthentication” keyword in all “sshd_config” files on the system to and set the value to "no". If Kerberos authentication is required it must be documented to include the location of the configuration file with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon does not permit Kerberos to authenticate passwords unless approved.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i kerberosauth <sshd_config file> KerberosAuthentication yes
If the “KerberosAuthentication” keyword is missing, is set to "no" and is not documented with the ISSO, or the returned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must perform strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log into the system as another user.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment the “StrictModes” keyword in all “sshd_config” files on the system and set the value to “yes”.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon performs strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name 'sshd*_config'
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i strictmodes <sshd_config file> StrictModes yes
If “StrictModes” is set to "no", is missing, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must use privilege separation.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment and/or modify the “UsePrivilegeSeparation” keyword in all sshd_config files on the system to “yes”.

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon performs privilege separation.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i usepriv <sshd_config file> UsePrivilegeSeparation sandbox
If the “UsePrivilegeSeparation” keyword is set to "no", is missing, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection, potentially with root privileges.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Uncomment and modify the “Compression” keywords in all “sshd_config” files on the system to "delayed" or "no".

check.check-content:
Verify that the SSH daemon performs compression after a user successfully authenticates.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
The command will return the full path of the ssh daemon. This will indicate which sshd_config file will be checked with the following command:
# grep –i compression <sshd_config file> Compression delayed
If the “Compression” keyword is set to “yes”, is missing, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The SSH server daemon must be configured for IP address access control.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The SSH server daemon must be configured to only allow access to known IP addresses or ranges to provide a layered defense against connection attempts from unauthorized addresses.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the ssh server daemon to use IP address access control by adding or modifying the “AllowUsers” keyword in the “/etc/ssh/sshd_config” to restrict access to known IP addresses or ranges.

check.check-content:
Verify that the ssh server daemon is configured to use IP address access control.
The location of the sshd_config file may vary on the system and can be found using the following command:
# find / -name ‘sshd*_config’
If there is more than one ssh server daemon configuration file on the system determine which daemons are active on the system with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep sshd
Check the configuration of the ssh server daemon with the following command:
# more /etc/ssh/sshd_config | grep –i allowusers AllowUsers *@192.168.21.* smithj@211.17.142.46
If the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file is not configured to use IP address access control inspect the /etc/hosts.allow file:
# grep ssh /etc/hosts.allow sshd: 192.168.21.0/255.255.255.0 sshd:211.17.142.46
If the /etc/hosts.allow file is not configured to use IP address access control for sshd then inspect the firewalld configuration:
# firewall-cmd --get-default-zone public
# firewall-cmd --list-all --zone=public public (default, active) interfaces: eth0 sources: services: mdns ssh ports: masquerade: no forward-ports: icmp-blocks: rich rules: rule family="ipv4" source address="92.188.21.1/24" accept rule family="ipv4" source address="211.17.142.46/32" accept
If the system is not configured to use IP address access control for sshd via the “sshd_config” file, the hosts.allow file, or the firewalld configuration, this is a finding.

Rule.title: A system used for routing must not run other network services or applications.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Installing extraneous software on a system designated as a dedicated router poses a security threat to the system and the network. Should an attacker gain access to the router through the unauthorized software, the entire network is susceptible to malicious activity.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the system is intended to be used as a router all network services other than routing must be disabled or removed. All hosted applications must be migrated to another system.
If the system is not intended to be used as a router then the files that contain entries that relate to bridging (BRIDGE= and TYPE=Bridge) must be removed from the system.

check.check-content:
Verify that a system used for routing must not run other network services or applications.
Check to see if bridging is configured on the system:
# grep –I bridge /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/* BRIDGE=br0 TYPE=Bridge
If a bridge is configured then the system is acting as a network routing. Inspect the system for other services such as applications, databases, or web servers:
# ps –ef | more root 2928 0.0 0.6 17648 7120 ? S Oct21 0:00 /usr/local/apache2/bin/httpd -k start nobody 2949 0.0 0.6 17648 6492 ? S Oct21 0:00 /usr/local/apache2/bin/httpd -k start nobody 2950 0.0 0.6 17648 6492 ? S Oct21 0:00 /usr/local/apache2/bin/httpd -k start
If a system acting as a router is hosting any application, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not be running any routing protocol daemons, unless the system is a router.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If the system is not being used as a router modify the /etc/quagga/daemons file and set all of the entries to “no”. If the system is going to be used as a router migrate all of the application, database, or web servers to another system.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system is not running any routing protocol daemons, unless the system is a router.
Check to see if the system is running any routing protocol daemons with the following command:
# cat /etc/quagga/daemons zebra=yes bgpd=yes ospfd=yes ospf6d=no ripd=no ripngd=no isisd=no
If the file does not exist, or all of the entries are set to “no”, this is not a finding.
If the file exists and has entries set to “yes” check to see if IP forwarding is enabled using the following command:.
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv4.ip_forward net.ipv4.ip_forward=1
If IP forwarding value is 1 and routing protocols are running inspect the system for other services such as applications, databases, or web servers:
# ps –ef | more root 2928 0.0 0.6 17648 7120 ? S Oct21 0:00 /usr/local/apache2/bin/httpd -k start nobody 2949 0.0 0.6 17648 6492 ? S Oct21 0:00 /usr/local/apache2/bin/httpd -k start nobody 2950 0.0 0.6 17648 6492 ? S Oct21 0:00 /usr/local/apache2/bin/httpd -k start
If the system is hosting any application, database, or web servers, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The Network File System (NFS) export configuration file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Failure to give ownership of the NFS export configuration file to root provides the designated owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/exports” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/exports

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/exports” file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/exports” with the following command:
# ls –al /etc /exports -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 280 Mar 27 11:08 exports
If the “/etc/exports” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The Network File System (NFS) export configuration file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Failure to give group-ownership of the NFS export configuration file to root or a system group provides the designated group-owner and possible unauthorized users with the potential to change system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/exports” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/exports

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/exports” file is group owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/exports” with the following command:
# ls –al /etc /exports -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 280 Mar 27 11:08 exports
If the “/etc/exports” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The Network File System (NFS) export configuration file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Excessive permissions on the NFS export configuration file could allow unauthorized modification of the file, which could result in Denial of Service to authorized NFS exports and the creation of additional unauthorized exports.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “/etc/exports” file to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/exports

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/exports” file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/exports” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc /exports -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 280 Mar 27 11:08 exports
If the “/etc/exports” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The Network File System (NFS) must be configured to use AUTH_GSS.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>When an NFS server is configured to use AUTH_SYS a selected userid and groupid are used to handle requests from the remote user. The userid and groupid could mistakenly or maliciously be set incorrectly. The AUTH_GSS method of authentication uses certificates on the server and client systems to more securely authenticate the remote mount request.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Update the “/etc/exports” and “/etc/fstab” files so that the options “sec” is defined for each file system and that the “sec” options does not have the “sys” setting. Ensure that the “sec” is defined as “krb5:krb5i:krb5p”.

check.check-content:
Verify that “AUTH_GSS’ is being used to authenticate Network File System (NFS) mounts.
To check if the system is exporting file systems via NFS look for any entries in the “/etc/exports” file with the following command:
# cat /etc/exports /mnt/export 192.168.21.17 (rw,sync,sec=krb5:krb5i:krb5p)
If the system is exporting file systems via NFS and has the sec option without the “krb5:krb5i:krb5p” settings, the sec option has the “sys” setting, or the “sec” option is missing, this is a finding.
To check if the system is importing an NFS file system look for any entries in the “/etc/fstab” file that have a file system type of “nfs” with the following command:
# cat /etc/fstab | grep nfs 192.168.21.5:/mnt/export /data1 nfs4 rw,sync ,soft,sec=sys, krb5:krb5i:krb5p
If the system is mounting file systems via NFS and has the sec option without the “krb5:krb5i:krb5p” settings, the sec option has the “sys” setting, or the “sec” option is missing, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have an Instant Messaging (IM) client configured to access servers outside of government control.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Instant messaging (IM) clients provide a way for a user to send a message to one or more other users in real time. Additional capabilities may include file transfer and support for distributed game playing. Communication between clients and associated directory services are managed through messaging servers. IM clients present a security issue when the clients route messages through servers not under Department of Defense (DoD) control. The obvious implication is potentially sensitive information could be intercepted or altered in the course of transmission. In order to reduce the potential for disclosure of sensitive government information and to ensure the validity of official government information, IM clients connecting to public IM services will not be installed. Clients used to access internal or DoD-controlled IM services are permitted but must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If Instant messaging (IM) client(s) are installed but not in use remove them. If they are in use configure them to connect to DoD controlled IM servers, or document their use with other U.S. Federal Agency servers with the ISSM.

check.check-content:
Due to the number of Instant Messaging (IM) clients available to Red Hat 7 it is difficult to develop an all-encompassing set of commands to detect their installation and use. Observation of the system desktop and asking the System Administrator about their use are the only reliable methods of detecting them.
If an IM client is installed check the appropriate configuration menu or file to determine which IM server(s) that the client utilizes. If any of the servers listed are not internal or the organization (same IP address range), are not controlled by the Department of Defense, or are not documented with the ISSM as an approved connection to another U.S. Federal Agency, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have an unauthorized peer-to-peer file-sharing application.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Peer-to-peer file-sharing software can result in the unintentional exfiltration of information. There are also many legal issues associated with these types of utilities including copyright infringement or other intellectual property issues. The ASD Memo "Use of Peer-to-Peer (P2P) File-Sharing Applications across the DoD" states the following:
“P2P file-sharing applications are authorized for use on DOD networks with approval by the appropriate Authorizing Official (AO). Documented requirements, security architecture, configuration management process, and a training program for users are all requirements within the approval process. The unauthorized use of application or services, including P2P applications, is prohibited, and such applications or services must be eliminated.”</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If peer-to-peer application(s) are installed but not in use remove them. If they are in use configure them to connect to DoD controlled servers and document their use with the ISSM.

check.check-content:
Due to the number of peer-to-peer applications available to Red Hat 7 it is difficult to develop an all-encompassing set of commands to detect their installation and use. Observation of the system desktop and asking the System Administrator about their use are the only reliable methods of detecting them.
If a peer-to-peer application is installed check the appropriate configuration menu or file to determine which server(s) that the application utilizes. If any of the servers listed are not internal or the organization (same IP address range) or are not documented with the ISSM as an approved connection, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The /etc/samba/smb.conf file allows access to other machines on the network and grants permissions to certain users. If it is owned by another user, the file may be maliciously modified and the samba configuration could be compromised.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner on the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/samba/smb.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/samba/smb.conf -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 425 May 11 11:08 smb.conf
If the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the group owner of the smb.conf file is not root or a system group, the file may be maliciously modified and the samba configuration could be compromised.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner on the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/samba/smb.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file is group owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/samba/smb.conf
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 425 May 11 11:08 smb.conf
If the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/samba/smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the smb.conf file has excessive permissions, the file may be maliciously modified and the samba configuration could be compromised.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file to “0644” with the following command:
# chmod 0644 /etc/samba/smb.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file has a mode of “0644” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/samba/smb.conf -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 425 May 11 11:08 smb.conf
If the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0644”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The samba service must not use the smbpasswd authentication method.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Samba has incorporated more secure methods of using passwords, such as tdbsam and ldap authentication as opposed to the historical method using smbpasswd, which is plain text. More secure authentication methods than smbpasswd must be used if the samba service is required.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure samba to use Trivial Data Base (tdbsam) or Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (ldapsam) methods of storing authentication information by setting the password backend parameter in “/etc/samba/smb.conf”.

check.check-content:
Verify that samba is using an authentication method other than “smbpasswd”.
Check for the samba authentication method with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep backend passdb backend = tdbsam
If the passdb backend parameter is “smbpasswd”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The samba password file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>In the event that smbpasswd is being used for backward compatibility the password file must be properly secured. If the smbpasswd file is not owned by root, it may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of samba accounts.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Determine the location of the password file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘smb passwd file’ smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
Set the owner of the password file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/samba/smbpasswd

check.check-content:
Verify that the samba password file is owned by root.
Check to see if samba is storing passwords locally in a file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep backend passdb backend = smbpasswd
If the “passdb” backend is not set to “smbpasswd”, this is Not Applicable.
If the “passdb” backend is set to “smbpasswd” determine the location of the password file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘smb passwd file’ smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
Check the owner of the password file with the following command:
