# ls –alL /etc/samba/smbpasswd -rw------- 1 root root 2301576 Nov 10 2014 smbpasswd
If the password file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The samba password file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>In the event that smbpasswd is being used for backward compatibility the password file must be properly secured. If the smbpasswd file is not group-owned by root, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of samba accounts.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Determine the location of the password file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘smb passwd file’ smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
Set the group owner of the password file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/samba/smbpasswd

check.check-content:
Verify that the samba password file is group owned by root.
Check to see if samba is storing passwords locally in a file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep backend passdb backend = smbpasswd
If the “passdb” backend is not set to “smbpasswd”, this is Not Applicable.
If the “passdb” backend is set to “smbpasswd” determine the location of the password file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘smb passwd file’ smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
Check the group owner of the password file with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/samba/smbpasswd -rw------- 1 root root 2301576 Nov 10 2014 smbpasswd
If the password file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The samba password file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>In the event that smbpasswd is being used for backward compatibility the password file must be properly secured. If the smbpasswd file has a mode more permissive than 0600, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of samba accounts.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Determine the location of the password file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘smb passwd file’ smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
Set the mode of the password file to “0600” with the following command:
# chmod 0600 /etc/samba/smbpasswd

check.check-content:
Verify that the samba password has a mode of “0600” or less permissive.
Check to see if samba is storing passwords locally in a file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep backend passdb backend = smbpasswd
If the “passdb” backend is not set to “smbpasswd”, this is Not Applicable.
If the “passdb” backend is set to “smbpasswd” determine the location of the password file with the following command:
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘smb passwd file’ smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd
Check the mode of the password file with the following command:
# ls –alL /etc/samba/smbpasswd -rw------- 1 root root 2301576 Nov 10 2014 smbpasswd
If the password file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Samba must use the hosts allow parameter for access control.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Samba increases the attack surface of the system and must be restricted to communicate only with systems requiring access.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Set the "hosts allow" parameter in the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file to only allow connections from the specific IP addresses or address ranges that need samba access.

check.check-content:
Verify that the “hosts allow” parameter is set to allow only specific IP addresses or address ranges to connect to the samba daemon.
Check the “hosts allow” parameter in the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file with the following command:
Note: The hosts allow parameter must be set in the global section of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file.
# cat /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘hosts allow’ hosts allow = 192.168.21.0/255.255.255.0
If the hosts allow parameter is set to “= #none” or “=*” then access control is disabled.
If the “hosts allow” parameter is set to not enforce access control to the samba daemon, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Samba must be configured to use an authentication mechanism other than guest.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The samba authentication method of guest does not provide for individual user identification and must not be used.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Add or uncomment the “auth methods” parameter in the global section of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file and set the option(s) to a method other than “guest”.

check.check-content:
Verify that the “auth methods” parameter does not include the “guest” method of authentication.
Check the “auth methods” parameter in the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file with the following command:
Note: The auth methods parameter must be set in the global section of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file.
# grep /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘auth methods’ auth methods = sam winbind
If the “auth methods” parameter includes the “guest” option, or is not defined, this is a finding.

Rule.title: Samba must be configured to use encrypted passwords.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Samba must be configured to protect authenticators. If samba passwords are stored as plain-text the user passwords may be read by those with access to the samba password file.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Samba should be configured to use Trivial Data Base (tdbsam) or Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (ldapsam) methods of storing authentication information instead of passwords. If passwords must be used for backward compatibility reasons they must be encrypted by adding or uncommenting the “encrypt passwords” parameter and setting it to “yes” in the /etc/samba/smb.conf file..

check.check-content:
Verify that passwords stored in the samba password file are encrypted.
Check to see if samba is storing passwords locally in a file with the following command:
# cat /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep backend passdb backend = smbpasswd
If “passdb” backend is not set to “smbpasswd”, this is Not Applicable.
If “passdb” backend is set to “smbpasswd” check the encrypt passwords parameter in the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file with the following command:
Note: The encrypt passwords parameter must be set in the global section of the “/etc/samba/smb.conf” file.
# more /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep ‘encrypt passwords’ encrypt passwords = yes
If the “encrypt passwords” parameter is not set to “yes”, or is not defined, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have an Internet Network News (INN) server installed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>INN servers access Usenet newsfeeds and store newsgroup articles. INN servers use the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP) to transfer information from the Usenet to the server and from the server to authorized remote hosts.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Remove the inn package from the system with the following command:
# yum remove inn

check.check-content:
Verify that an Internet Network News (INN) server has not been installed.
Check for the INN package with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep inn
If any line is returned indicating an INN server has been installed, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must have a host-based intrusion detection/prevention tool installed.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Without a host-based intrusion detection tool, there is no system-level defense when an intruder gains access to a system or network. Additionally, a host-based intrusion prevention tool can provide methods to immediately lock out detected intrusion attempts.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Install and configure the McAfee Common Management Agent and runtime libraries. If the Host Based Security System is not available install an alternate host-based intrusion detection or prevention system application.

check.check-content:
Verify that a host-based intrusion detection (HID) or prevention system (HIPS) is installed.
Check for the installation of the McAfee Common Management Agent (CMA) and runtime libraries (MFErt) with the following commands:
# yum list installed | grep MFEcma MFEcma.i686.rpm
# yum list installed | grep MFErt MFErt.i686.rpm
If the packages are installed check to see if the CMA is active with the following command:
# ps –ef | grep cma
If the packages are not installed ask the system administrator if there is a host-based intrusion or prevention system installed other than the Common Management Agent, and have them execute a process listing that indicates the HID/HIPS is active.
If the CMA is not installed or is not active, or another HID/HIPS application is not installed and active, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system vulnerability assessment tool, host-based intrusion detection/prevention tool, and file integrity tool must notify the SA and the ISSO of a security violation or a suspected security violation.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Timely notifications of potential security compromises minimize the potential damage.
Minimally, the system must log these events and the SA and the ISSO will receive the notifications during the daily system log review. If feasible, active alerting (such as e-mail or paging) should be employed consistent with the site’s established operations management systems and procedures.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the security tools on the system to notify System Administrators and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) when any security violations are detected.

check.check-content:
Ask the system administrator which system vulnerability assessment tool(s), host-based intrusion detection/prevention tool(s), and file integrity tool(s) are installed on the system. Ask them to demonstrate that the tools send alerts or email notifications of potential security violations to the System Administrators and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) by observing their ePO remote console, other management application, or emails sent by the tools.
If no system vulnerability tool(s), host-based intrusion detection/prevention tools(s), or file integrity tool(s) are installed on the system, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The file integrity tool must be configured to verify ACLs.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>ACLs can provide permissions beyond those permitted through the file mode and must be verified by file integrity tools.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the file integrity tool to check file and directory acls. If “aide” is installed ensure that the “acl” rule is present on all file and directory selection lists.

check.check-content:
Verify that the file integrity tool is configured to verify ACLs.
Check to see if “aide” is installed on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep aide
If “aide” is not installed ask the System Administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system.
If there is no application installed to perform integrity checks, this is a finding.
Note: “aide” is highly configurable at install time if complied on the system.
These commands assume that the “aide.conf” file is under the “/etc directory”. Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:
# find / -name aide.conf
Check the “aide.conf” file to determine if the “acl” rule has been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists.
An example rule that includes the acl rule is below:
All= p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux /bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin /sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin
If the “acl” rule is not being used on all selection lines in the “/etc/aide.conf” file, or acls are not being checked by another file integrity tool, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The file integrity tool must be configured to verify extended attributes.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Extended attributes in file systems are used to contain arbitrary data and file metadata with security implications.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the file integrity tool to check file and directory extended attributes. If “aide” is installed ensure that the “xattrs” rule is present on all file and directory selection lists.

check.check-content:
Verify that the file integrity tool is configured to verify extended attributes.
Check to see if “aide” is installed on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep aide
If “aide” is not installed ask the system administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system.
If there is no application installed to perform integrity checks, this is a finding.
Note: aide is highly configurable at install time if complied on the system.
These commands assume that the “aide.conf” file is under the “/etc directory”. Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:
# find / -name aide.conf
Check the “aide.conf” file to determine if the “xattrs” rule has been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists. An example rule that includes the “xattrs” rule is below:
All= p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux /bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin /sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin
If the "xattrs" rule is not being used on all selection lines in the “/etc/aide.conf” file, or extended attributes are not being checked by another file integrity tool, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The file integrity tool must use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents and directories.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>File integrity tools use cryptographic hashes for verifying that file contents and directories have not been altered. These hashes must be FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the file integrity tool to use FIPS 140-2 cryptographic hashes for validating file and directory contents. If “aide” is installed ensure that the “sha512” rule is present on all file and directory selection lists.

check.check-content:
Verify that the file integrity tool is configured to use FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents and directories.
Check to see if “aide” is installed on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep aide
If “aide” is not installed ask the system administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system.
If there is no application installed to perform integrity checks, this is a finding.
Note: “aide” is highly configurable at install time if complied on the system.
These commands assume that the “aide.conf” file is under the “/etc directory”. Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:
# find / -name aide.conf
Check the “aide.conf” file to determine if the “sha512” rule has been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists. An example rule that includes the sha512 rule is below:
All=p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux /bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin /sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin
If the “sha512” rule is not being used on all selection lines in the “/etc/aide.conf” file, or another file integrity tool is not using FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashes for validating file contents and directories, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must use an access control program.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Access control methods provide the ability to enhance system security posture by restricting services to known good IP addresses and address ranges. This prevents connections from unknown hosts and protocols.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Install “firewalld” on the system if it is not already installed with the following command:
# yum install firewalld firewall-config
If there are “xinetd” services that are active on the system install “tcpwrappers” if it is not already installed with the following command:
# yum install tcp_wrappers

check.check-content:
Verify that an access control program is in use on the system.
Check to see if “firewalld” is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep firewalld
If “firewalld” is not installed check to see if “tcpwrappers” is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep tcpwrappers
If neither “firewalld” nor “tcpwrappers” is installed ask the System Administrator if there is another method of access control that they are performing for all network services on the system.
If there is no access control being performed on all network services, this is a finding.
If “firewalld” is installed determine whether it is active with the following command:
# systemctl status firewalld firewalld.service - firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/firewalld.service; enabled) Active: active (running) since Sun 2014-04-20 14:06:46 BST; 30s ago
If “firewalld” is not active determine whether “tcpwrappers” is being used by checking whether the “hosts.allow” and “hosts.deny” files are empty with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/hosts.allow rw-r----- 1 root root 0 Aug 2 23:13 /etc/hosts.allow
# ls –al /etc/hosts.deny -rw-r----- 1 root root 0 Apr 9 2007 /etc/hosts.deny
If “firewalld” is not active, and the “hosts.allow” and “hosts.deny” files are empty, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The systems access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: If “firewalld” is installed and active on the system configure rules for allowing specific services and hosts. If “tcpwrappers” is installed configure the “/etc/hosts.allow” and “/etc/hosts.deny” to allow or deny access to specific hosts.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system's access control program is configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
Check to see if “firewalld” is active with the following command:
# systemctl status firewalld firewalld.service - firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/firewalld.service; enabled) Active: active (running) since Sun 2014-04-20 14:06:46 BST; 30s ago
If “firewalld” is active check to see if it is configured to grant or deny access to specific hosts or services with the following commands:
# firewall-cmd --get-default-zone public
# firewall-cmd --list-all --zone=public public (default, active) interfaces: eth0 sources: services: mdns ssh ports: masquerade: no forward-ports: icmp-blocks: rich rules: rule family="ipv4" source address="92.188.21.1/24" accept rule family="ipv4" source address="211.17.142.46/32" accept
If “firewalld” is not active determine whether “tcpwrappers” is being used by checking whether the “hosts.allow” and “hosts.deny” files are empty with the following commands:
# ls –al /etc/hosts.allow rw-r----- 1 root root 9 Aug 2 23:13 /etc/hosts.allow
# ls –al /etc/hosts.deny -rw-r----- 1 root root 9 Apr 9 2007 /etc/hosts.deny
If “firewalld” is active and is not configured to grant access to specific hosts and “tcpwrappers” is not configured to grant or deny access to specific hosts, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must use a DoD-approved virus scan program.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Virus scanning software can be used to protect a system from penetration from computer viruses and to limit their spread through intermediate systems.
The virus scanning software should be configured to perform scans dynamically on accessed files. If this capability is not available, the system must be configured to scan, at a minimum, all altered files on the system on a daily basis.
If the system processes inbound SMTP mail, the virus scanner must be configured to scan all received mail.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Install an approved DoD anti-virus solution on the system.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system is using a DoD-approved virus scan program.
Check for the presence of “McAfee VirusScan Enterprise for Linux” with the following command
# systemctl status nails
nails - service for McAfee VirusScan Enterprise for Linux > Loaded: loaded /opt/NAI/package/McAfeeVSEForLinux/McAfeeVSEForLinux-2.0.2.<build_number>; enabled) > Active: active (running) since Mon 2015-09-27 04:11:22 UTC;21 min ago
If the “nails” service is not active check for the presence of “clamav” on the system with the following command:
# systemctl status clamav-daemon.socket systemctl status clamav-daemon.socket clamav-daemon.socket - Socket for Clam AntiVirus userspace daemon Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/clamav-daemon.socket; enabled) Active: active (running) since Mon 2015-01-12 09:32:59 UTC; 7min ago
If neither of these applications are loaded and active ask the SA if there is an anti-virus package installed and active on the system. If no anti-virus scan program is active on the system, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must update the DoD-approved virus scan program every seven days or more frequently.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>Virus scanning software can be used to protect a system from penetration from computer viruses and to limit their spread through intermediate systems.
The virus scanning software should be configured to check for software and virus definition updates with a frequency no longer than seven days. If a manual process is required to update the virus scan software or definitions it must be documented with the ISSM.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Update the approved DoD virus scan software and virus definition files.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system is using a DoD-approved virus scan program and that the virus definition file is less than seven days old.
Check for the presence of “McAfee VirusScan Enterprise for Linux” with the following command
# systemctl status nails nails - service for McAfee VirusScan Enterprise for Linux > Loaded: loaded /opt/NAI/package/McAfeeVSEForLinux/McAfeeVSEForLinux-2.0.2.<build_number>; enabled) > Active: active (running) since Mon 2015-09-27 04:11:22 UTC;21 min ago
If the “nails” service is not active check for the presence of “clamav” on the system with the following command:
# systemctl status clamav-daemon.socket systemctl status clamav-daemon.socket clamav-daemon.socket - Socket for Clam AntiVirus userspace daemon Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/clamav-daemon.socket; enabled) Active: active (running) since Mon 2015-01-12 09:32:59 UTC; 7min ago
If “McAfee VirusScan Enterprise for Linux” is active on the system check the dates of the virus definition files with the following command:
# ls –al /opt/NAI/LinuxShield/engine/dat/*.dat <need output>
If the virus definition files have dates older than seven days from the current date, this is a finding.
If “clamav” is active on the system check the dates of the virus database with the following commands:
# grep –I databasedirectory /etc/clamav.conf DatabaseDirectory /var/lib/clamav
# ls –al /var/lib/clamav/*.cvd -rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 149156 Mar 5 2011 daily.cvd
If the database file has a date older than seven days from the current date, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have unauthorized IP tunnels configured.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>IP tunneling mechanisms can be used to bypass network filtering. If tunneling is required it must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Remove all unapproved tunnels from the system, or document them with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not have unauthorized IP tunnels configured.
Check to see if “libreswan” is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed libreswan openswan-2.6.32-27.el6.x86_64
If “libreswan” is installed check to see if the “IPsec” service is active with the following command:
# systemctl status ipsec ipsec.service - Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Protocol Daemon for IPsec Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/ipsec.service; disabled) Active: inactive (dead)
If the “IPsec” service is active check to see if any tunnels are configured in “/etc/ipsec.conf” and “/etc/ipsec.d/” with the following commands:
# grep –i conn /etc/ipsec.conf conn mytunnel
# grep -i include /etc/ipsec.conf include /etc/ipsec.d/*.conf
# grep –i conn /etc/ipsec.d/*.conf conn mytunnel
If there are indications that a “conn” parameter is configured for a tunnel, ask the SA if the tunnel is documented with the ISSO. If “libreswan” is installed, “IPsec” is active, and an undocumented tunnel is active, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The DHCP client must not send dynamic DNS updates.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Dynamic DNS updates transmit unencrypted information about a system including its name and address and should not be used unless needed.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Set the value of the “PEERDNS” option to “no” in the network device configuration files found in the “/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts” subdirectory.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system is configured to not send Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) updates.
Check the client DHCP configuration with the following command:
# grep –i peerdns /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts PEERDNS=no PEERDNS=no
If any of the lines returned have a value of "yes", this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must ignore IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv4 packets with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not accept IPv6 source-routed packets.
Check the value of the accept source route variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0
If the returned lines does not have a value of “0”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when IPv6 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not accept source-routed IPv6 packets with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not accept IPv6 source-routed packets.
Check the value of the accept source route variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0
If the returned lines do not have a value of “0”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not respond to IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo requests sent to a broadcast address.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Responding to broadcast ICMP echo requests facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Configure the system to not respond to ICMP echo requests sent to broadcast addresses with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl -w net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts = 1

check.check-content:
Verify that the system does not respond to IPv6 ICMP echoes sent to a broadcast address.
Check the value of the “icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts” variable with the following command:
# /sbin/sysctl –a | grep icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts net.ipv6.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1
If the returned line does not have a value of “1”, a line is not returned, or the retuned line is commented out, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP for authentication or account information, the system must use a TLS connection using FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>OpenLDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. Communication between an OpenLDAP server and a host using OpenLDAP requires an encrypted authentication method.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
To configure OpenLDAP to use a TLS connection utilizing FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms for communication create a file with the following entries:
Note: The file can be named anything but must end in .ldif (/etc/openldap/slapd.d/change.ldif will be used for the example). The directory paths must also be modified to reflect the local OpenLDAP configuration (/etc/ssl/certs will be used for the example).
dn: olcDatabase={0}config.ldif,cn=config changetype: modify replace: olcDisallows olcDisallows: bind_anon bind_simple dn: cn=config changetype: modify replace: olcTLSCertificateFile olcTLSCACertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem dn: cn=config changetype: modify replace: olcTLSCACertificateKeyFile olcTLSCertificateKeyFile: /etc/ssl/private/server-key.pem dn: cn=config changetype: modify replace: olcTLSCertificateFile olcTLSCertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/server-cert.pem dn: cn=config changetype: modify replace: olcTLSCertificateKeyFile olcTLSCertificateKeyFile: /etc/ssl/certs /priv.pem
Then commit the changes with the following command:
# ldapmodify -Y EXTERNAL -H ldapi:/// -f /etc/openldap/slapd.d/change.ldif

check.check-content:
Verify that OpenLDAP is using a TLS connection utilizing FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic algorithms for communication that involves authentication or account information.
Check to see if “openldap” is active with the following command:
# systemctl status slapd.service slapd.service - LSB: OpenLDAP standalone server (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) Loaded: loaded (/etc/init.d/slapd) Active: active (running) since Wed 2015-04-22 10:59:45 BST; 7s ago Docs: man:systemd-sysv-generator(8) CGroup: /system.slice/slapd.service ??1507 /usr/sbin/slapd -h ldap:/// ldapi:/// -g openldap -u openldap -F /etc/openldap/slapd.d
If the “slapd.service” is not active, this is Not A Finding.
If it is active check to see if TLS is configured with the following commands:
Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”
# grep -i olctlscacertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCACertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem
# grep olctlscacertificatekeyfile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCertificateKeyFile: /etc/ssl/private/server-key.pem
# grep -i olctlscertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/server-cert.pem
# grep -i olctlcsertificatekeyFile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCertificateKeyFile: /etc/ssl/certs /priv.pem
If any of the four directives are missing, commented out, or not configured, this is a finding.
If all four directives exist and are configured check for enforcement of TLS on all connections with the following command:
#grep -i olcdisallows /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcDisallows: bind_anon bind_simple
If the "olcDisallows" directive is not configured with both "bind_anon" and "bind_simple", this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP for authentication or account information, certificates used to authenticate to the OpenLDAP server must be provided from DoD PKI or a DoD-approved external certificate authority.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>OpenLDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. Communication between an OpenLDAP server and a host using OpenLDAP must authenticated using certificates that are from a trusted certificate authority.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Obtain a TLS certificate file from the DoD PKI office or a DoD-approved external certificate authority.

check.check-content:
Verify that the certificates used to authenticate to the OpenLDAP server are provided from DoD PKI or a DoD-approved external certificate authority.
Check to see if “openldap” is active with the following command:
# systemctl status slapd.service slapd.service - LSB: OpenLDAP standalone server (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) Loaded: loaded (/etc/init.d/slapd) Active: active (running) since Wed 2015-04-22 10:59:45 BST; 7s ago Docs: man:systemd-sysv-generator(8) CGroup: /system.slice/slapd.service ??1507 /usr/sbin/slapd -h ldap:/// ldapi:/// -g openldap -u openldap -F /etc/openldap/slapd.d
If the “slapd.service” is not active, this is Not a Finding.
If it is active check for the location of the TLS certificate authority file with the following command:
Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”
# grep -i olctlscacertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCACertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem
Determine the issuer of the certificate with the following command:
# openssl x509 –in /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem -noout –issuer Issuer: CN=DoD Interoperability Root CA 1,OU=PKI,OU=DoD,O=U.S. Government,C=US
If the certificate was not issued by DoD PKI, or a DoD-approved external certificate authority, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP for authentication or account information, the OpenLDAP TLS connection must require the server provide a certificate with a valid trust path to a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The OpenLDAP service provides user mappings which are a vital component of system security. Communication between an OpenLDAP server and a host using LDAP requires certificates that are issued by a trusted CA.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Obtain a root certificate from the DoD Certificate Authority (CA), or an approved External Certificate Authority, and configure “OpenLDAP” to point to this certificate. Re-issue and certificates that were signed by the unapproved CA certificate.

check.check-content:
Verify that the OpenLDAP server has a certificate with a valid trust path to a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).
Check the CA trust path with the following command:
Note: The following example will return results that do not meet the requirement.
# openssl verify -verbose -purpose all sslserver –CAfile /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem /etc/ssl/certs/server-cert.pem Tue Jun 05 09:52:22 2007 VERIFY ERROR: depth=1, error=self signed certificate in certificate chain: /C=US/ST=AZ/L=HEWC/O=HEWC/CN=linux/emailAddress=badaddress@gmail.com
If the command returns an error referencing a self-signed certificate, or a certificate has not been issued by a DoD CA or an approved External Certificate Authority (ECA), this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP the configuration files must not contain passwords.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The authentication of automated OpenLDAP connections between systems must not use passwords since more secure methods are available, such as PKI and Kerberos. Additionally, the storage of unencrypted passwords on the system is not permitted.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure OpenLDAP to use the Simple Authentication and Security Layer (SASL) framework for authentication instead of passwords.

check.check-content:
Verify that the “OpenLDAP” configuration files do not contain passwords.
Check for the presence of passwords in the “OpenLDAP” configuration files with the following commands:
Note: The “userPassword” and “olcRootPW” options may be found as declarations in some of the OLC configuration files.
Note: In the following examples the second returned result does not meet the requirement.
#grep –iR userpassword /etc/openldap/slapd.d userPassword: {CRYPT}frzelFSD.VhkI userPassword: admin1963secret
#grep –iR olcrootpw /etc/openldap/slapd.d olcRootPW: {SSHA}ZKKuqbEKJfKSXhUbHG3fG8MDn9j1v4QN olcRootPW: admin1963secret
If the commands return lines in the OLC configuration files that have passwords set, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP the configuration files must have a mode of 0644 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>OpenLDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. The OpenLDAP client configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “OpenLDAP” configuration files under “/etc/openldap/slapd.d” file to “0640” with the following command:
# chmod 0640 /etc/openldap/slapd.d/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that the “OpenLDAP” configuration files have a mode of “0640” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “OpenLDAP” configuration files with the following command:
# ls –alLR /etc/openldap/slapd.d drwxr-x---. 3 ldap ldap 4096 Sep 13 14:12 . drwx------. 3 ldap ldap 43 Sep 13 14:12 .. drwxr-x---. 2 ldap ldap 28 Sep 13 14:12 cn=schema -rw-r-----. 1 ldap ldap 378 Sep 13 14:12 cn=schema.ldif -rw-r-----. 1 ldap ldap 513 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={0}config.ldif -rw-r-----. 1 ldap ldap 439 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={-1}frontend.ldif -rw-r-----. 1 ldap ldap 562 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={1}monitor.ldif -rw-r-----. 1 ldap ldap 609 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={2}hdb.ldif
If any of the “OpenLDAP” configuration files have a mode more permissive then “0640”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP the configuration files must be owned by the ldap user account.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>OpenLDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. The LDAP client configuration must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of the “OpenLDAP” configuration files under “/etc/openldap/slapd.d” file to “ldap” with the following command:
# chown ldap /etc/openldap/slapd.d/<file>

check.check-content:
Verify that the OpenLDAP configuration files are owned by ldap.
Check the owner of the OpenLDAP configuration files with the following command:
# l s –alLR /etc/openldap/slapd.d drwxr-x---. 3 ldap ldap 4096 Sep 13 14:12 . drwx------. 3 ldap ldap 43 Sep 13 14:12 .. drwxr-x---. 2 ldap ldap 28 Sep 13 14:12 cn=schema -rw-------. 1 ldap ldap 378 Sep 13 14:12 cn=schema.ldif -rw-------. 1 ldap ldap 513 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={0}config.ldif -rw-------. 1 ldap ldap 439 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={-1}frontend.ldif -rw-------. 1 ldap ldap 562 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={1}monitor.ldif -rw-------. 1 ldap ldap 609 Sep 13 14:12 olcDatabase={2}hdb.ldif
If any of the “OpenLDAP” configuration files have an owner other than “ldap”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP the TLS certificate authority file must be owned by ldap.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>OpenLDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. The LDAP client certificate authority file must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>

Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”
# grep -i olctlscacertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCACertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem
Change the owner of the TLS certificate authority file to “ldap” with the following command:
# chown ldap /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem

check.check-content:
Verify that the “OpenLDAP” TLS certificate authority file is owned by “ldap”.
Check to see if “openldap” is active with the following command:
# systemctl status slapd.service slapd.service - LSB: OpenLDAP standalone server (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) Loaded: loaded (/etc/init.d/slapd) Active: active (running) since Wed 2015-04-22 10:59:45 BST; 7s ago Docs: man:systemd-sysv-generator(8) CGroup: /system.slice/slapd.service ??1507 /usr/sbin/slapd -h ldap:/// ldapi:/// -g openldap -u openldap -F /etc/openldap/slapd.d
If the “slapd.service” is not active, this is Not a Finding.
If it is active, check for the location of the TLS certificate authority file with the following command:
Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”
# grep -i olctlscacertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCACertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem
Then check the owner of the TLS certificate authority file with the following command:
# ls -la /etc/ssl/certs/cacert.pem -rw-r-----. 1 ldap ldap 1070 Aug 25 04:41 cacert.pem
If the TLS certificate authority file has an owner other than “ldap”, this is a finding.

Verify that the “OpenLDAP” TLS certificate file has a mode of “0640” or less permissive.
Check to see if “openldap” is active with the following command:
# systemctl status slapd.service slapd.service - LSB: OpenLDAP standalone server (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) Loaded: loaded (/etc/init.d/slapd) Active: active (running) since Wed 2015-04-22 10:59:45 BST; 7s ago Docs: man:systemd-sysv-generator(8) CGroup: /system.slice/slapd.service ??1507 /usr/sbin/slapd -h ldap:/// ldapi:/// -g openldap -u openldap -F /etc/openldap/slapd.d
If the “slapd.service” is not active, this is Not a Finding.
If it is active, check for the location of the TLS certificate file with the following command:
Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”
# grep -i olctlscertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/server-cert.pem
Then check the mode of the TLS certificate file with the following command:
# ls -la /etc/ssl/certs/server-cert.pem -rw-------. 1 ldap ldap 1164 Aug 25 14:05 server-cert.pem
If the TLS certificate file has a mode more permissive than “0640”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: If the system is using OpenLDAP, the LDAP TLS certificate key file must be owned by ldap.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>OpenLDAP can be used to provide user authentication and account information, which are vital to system security. The LDAP TLS key must be protected from unauthorized modification.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Find the location of the TLS certificate key file with the following command:
Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”
# grep -i olctlscertificatefile /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif olcTLSCertificateFile: /etc/ssl/certs/priv.pem
Change the owner of the TLS certificate key file to “ldap” with the following command:
# chown ldap /etc/ssl/certs/priv.pem

check.check-content:
Verify that the “OpenLDAP” TLS certificate key file is owned by ldap.
Check to see if “openldap” is active with the following command:
# systemctl status slapd.service slapd.service - LSB: OpenLDAP standalone server (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) Loaded: loaded (/etc/init.d/slapd) Active: active (running) since Wed 2015-04-22 10:59:45 BST; 7s ago Docs: man:systemd-sysv-generator(8) CGroup: /system.slice/slapd.service ??1507 /usr/sbin/slapd -h ldap:/// ldapi:/// -g openldap -u openldap -F /etc/openldap/slapd.d
If the “slapd.service” is not active, this is Not A Finding.

Note: The example uses the file “/etc/openldap/slapd.d/cn=config.ldif”

If the owner of the TLS certificate key is other than “ldap”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must have USB mass storage disabled unless approved.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>USB is a common computer peripheral interface. USB devices may include storage devices with the potential to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data. USB mass storage support may be required to rotate logs off of the system, and must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Add the following configuration line to the “/etc/modprobe.d/50-blacklist.conf” file: blacklist usb_storage
If the file does not exist create it and add the required configuration line.

check.check-content:
Verify that USB mass storage has been disabled.
Check to see of USB mass storage has been disabled with the following command:
# grep usb_storage /etc/modprobe.d/50-blacklist.conf blacklist usb_storage
If the “50-blacklist.conf” file does not contain a line blacklisting USB storage, or the file is not present this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must employ a local firewall.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave. If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Install “firewalld” and the other required packages with the following command:
# yum install firewalld firewall-configfirewalld-<version>.noarch
Configure “firewalld” to only allow required and documented network services.

check.check-content:
Verify that a local firewall in use on the system.
Check to see if firewalld is installed with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep firewalld firewalld-0.3.9-7.el7.noarch
If “firewalld” is installed determine whether it is active with the following command:
# systemctl status firewalld firewalld.service - firewalld - dynamic firewall daemon Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/firewalld.service; enabled) Active: active (running) since Sun 2014-04-20 14:06:46 BST; 30s ago
If the “firewalld” package is not installed, or is not active, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not allow removable media to be used as the boot loader unless approved.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Malicious users with removable boot media can gain access to a system configured to use removable media as the boot loader. If removable media is designed to be used as the boot loader the requirement must be documented with the ISSO.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Remove alternate methods of booting the system from removable media or document the configuration to boot from removable media with the ISSO.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system is not configured to use a boot loader on removable media.
Note: GRUB 2 reads its configuration from the “/boot/grub2/grub.cfg” file on traditional BIOS-based machines and from the “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” file on UEFI machines.
Check for the existence of alternate boot loader configuration files with the following command:
# find / -name grub.conf /boot/grub2/grub.cfg /mnt/usb/boot/grub/grub.cfg
If a “grub.cfg” is found in any subdirectories other than “/boot/grub2” and “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat” ask the SA if there is documentation signed by the ISSO to approve the use of removable media as a boot loader.
If the system is using an alternate boot loader on removable media, and documentation does not exist approving the alternate configuration, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system boot loader must require authentication.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>If the system's boot loader does not require authentication, users with console access to the system may be able to alter the system boot configuration or boot the system into single user or maintenance mode, which could result in Denial of Service or unauthorized privileged access to the system.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
As root, create a password for each user that requires the ability to boot the system:
# grub2-mkpasswd-pbkdf2 command
Copy the password into the “/etc/grub.d/01_users” file for the appropriate user.

check.check-content:
Verify that the system boot loader requires authentication.
Check for the “GRUB 2” boot loader user configuration file with the following command:
# more /etc/grub.d/01_users
Note: The entry for the user jane is an example of an incorrect configuration.
set superusers="john" password_pbkdf2 john grub.pbkdf2.sha512.10000.19074739ED80F115963D984BDCB35AA671C24325755377C3E9B014D862DA6ACC77BC110EED41822800A87FD3700C037320E51E9326188D53247EC0722DDF15FC.C56EC0738911AD86CEA55546139FEBC366A393DF9785A8F44D3E51BF09DB980BAFEF85281CBBC56778D8B19DC94833EA8342F7D73E3A1AA30B205091F1015A85 password jane janespassword
If the “/etc/grub.d/01_users” file does not exist, or it does not contain a “password_pbkdf2” entry for each user, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The systems boot loader configuration file(s) must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>File permissions greater than 0600 on boot loader configuration files could allow an unauthorized user to view or modify sensitive information pertaining to system boot instructions</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “GRUB 2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
Note: “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” will be used in the example.
# chmod 0600 /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg

check.check-content:
Verify that the system's boot loader configuration file has a mode “0600” or less permissive.
Note: “GRUB 2” reads its configuration from the “/boot/grub2/grub.cfg” file on traditional BIOS-based machines and from the “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” file on UEFI machines.
Check for the location of the “grub2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
# find / -name grub.conf /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
Check the mode of the “grub2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
# ls –al /boot/grub2/grub.cfg -r-------- 1 root root 2453 May 13 17:22 /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
If the mode of the “grub2” configuration file is more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The systems boot loader configuration files must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The system's boot loader configuration files are critical to the integrity of the system and must be protected. Unauthorized modification of these files resulting from improper ownership could compromise the system's boot loader configuration.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the owner of the “GRUB 2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
Note: “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” will be used in the example.
# chown root /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg

check.check-content:
Verify that the system's boot loader configuration file is owned by root.
Note: “GRUB 2” reads its configuration from the “/boot/grub2/grub.cfg” file on traditional BIOS-based machines and from the “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” file on UEFI machines.
Check for the location of the “grub2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
# find / -name grub.conf /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
Check the owner of the grub2 boot loader configuration file with the following command:
# ls –al /boot/grub2/grub.cfg -r-------- 1 root root 2453 May 13 17:22 /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
If the “grub2” configuration file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The systems boot loader configuration file(s) must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The system's boot loader configuration files are critical to the integrity of the system and must be protected. Unauthorized modifications resulting from improper group ownership may compromise the boot loader configuration.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the group owner of the “GRUB 2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
Note: “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” will be used in the example.
# chgrp root /boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg

check.check-content:
Verify that the system's boot loader configuration file is group owned by root.
Note: “GRUB 2” reads its configuration from the “/boot/grub2/grub.cfg” file on traditional BIOS-based machines and from the “/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg” file on UEFI machines.
Check for the location of the “grub2” boot loader configuration file with the following command:
# find / -name grub.conf /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
Check the group owner of the “grub2” boot loader configuration file with the following command: # ls –al /boot/grub2/grub.cfg -r-------- 1 root root 2453 May 13 17:22 /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
If the “grub2” configuration file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system package management tool must not automatically obtain updates.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>System package management tools can obtain a list of updates and patches from a package repository and make this information available to the SA for review and action. Using a package repository outside of the organization's control presents a risk of malicious packages being introduced.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
If the yum-cron package is installed set the “download_updates” option to “no” in “/etc/yum/yum-cron.conf”:
download_updates = no

check.check-content:
Verify that he system package management tool does not automatically obtain updates.
Check for the presence of the yum-cron package with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep yum-cron yum-cron-3.4.3-508.fc24.noarch.rpm
If the package is installed check to see if it automatically downloads updates with the following command:
# grep download_updates /etc/yum/yum-cron.conf download_updates = no
If the “download_updates” option is set to “yes”, this is a finding.

Rule.title: A system file integrity baseline configured to track core software must exist.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>A file integrity baseline is a collection of file metadata which is to evaluate the integrity of the system. A minimal baseline must contain metadata for all device files, setuid files, setgid files, system libraries, system binaries, and system configuration files. The minimal metadata must consist of the mode, owner, group owner, and modification times. For regular files, metadata must also include file size and a cryptographic hash of the file’s contents.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the system file integrity tool to check all device files, setuid files, setgid files, system libraries, system binaries, and system configuration files. The minimal configuration must consist of the mode, owner, group owner, and modification times. For regular files it must also include file size and a cryptographic hash of the file’s contents.

check.check-content:
Verify that a system file integrity baseline with the required attributes has been created.
Check to see if “aide” is installed on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep aide
If “aide” is not installed ask the System Administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system.
If there is no application installed to perform integrity checks, this is a finding.
Note: “aide” is highly configurable at install time if complied on the system. These commands assume that the “aide.conf” file is under the “/etc directory”. Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:
# find / -name aide.conf
An example rule that includes all of the required attributes would be:
All=p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux /bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin /sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin
Check the “aide.conf” file to determine if the required rules have been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists with the following command:
# cat /etc/aide.conf | more
Check each of the file and directory selections for the required attributes.
Note: Not all files and directories will have all of the attributes as they will not directly apply (such as some log directories under /var). Determine where the database is being written to with the following command:
# grep database_out /etc/aide.conf database_out=file:/var/lib/aide/aide.db.new
Check to see if the database file exists with the following command:
# ls –al /var/lib/aide/aide.db.new -rw------- 1 root root 1520639 Dec 8 16:57 aide.db.new
If the required rule is not being used on all selection lines in the “/etc/aide.conf” file, or a system file integrity baseline has not been created (either with “aide” or by another file integrity tool), this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system file integrity baseline must be updated to reduce false positives.
Rule.description:
<VulnDiscussion>A file integrity baseline is a collection of file hashes and metadata which are used to evaluate the integrity of the system. A minimal baseline must contain hashes for all device files, setuid files, setgid files, system libraries, system binaries, and system configuration files. The minimal metadata must consist of the mode, owner, group owner, and modification times. For regular files, metadata must also include file size.
Over time the system will deviate from the baseline as approved system configuration changes are made and patches are applied. This will result in the file integrity tool reporting more and more false positives until it becomes difficult to determine malicious activity on the system. The file integrity baseline must be periodically recreated to account for these changes.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Configure the system file integrity tool to check all device files, setuid files, setgid files, system libraries, system binaries, and system configuration files. The minimal configuration must consist of the mode, owner, group owner, and modification times. For regular files it must also include file size and a cryptographic hash of the file’s contents. Update the system file integrity tool database when packages have been added, removed, or modified, or major changes have been made to the system configuration.

check.check-content:
Verify that a system file integrity baseline with the required attributes is being maintained.
Check to see if “aide” is installed on the system with the following command:
# yum list installed | grep aide
If “aide” is not installed ask the system administrator how file integrity checks are performed on the system. If there is no application installed to perform integrity checks, this is a finding.
Note: “aide” is highly configurable at install time if complied on the system. These commands assume that the aide.conf file is under the “/etc directory”. Use the following command to determine if the file is in another location:
# find / -name aide.conf
An example rule that includes all of the required attributes would be:
All=p+i+n+u+g+s+m+S+sha512+acl+xattrs+selinux /bin All # apply the custom rule to the files in bin /sbin All # apply the same custom rule to the files in sbin
Check the “aide.conf” file to determine if the required rules have been added to the rule list being applied to the files and directories selection lists with the following command:
# cat /etc/aide.conf | more
Check each of the file and directory selections for the required attributes.
Note: Not all files and directories will have all of the attributes as they will not directly apply (such as some log directories under /var).
Determine where the database is being written to with the following command:
# grep database_out /etc/aide.conf database_out=file:/var/lib/aide/aide.db.new
Check to see if the database file exists with the following command:
# ls –al /var/lib/aide/aide.db.new -rw------- 1 root root 1520639 Dec 8 16:57 aide.db.new
Check to see the last time packages have been installed, removed, or modified with the following command:
# yum history info Loaded plugins: fastestmirror, langpacks Transaction ID : 12 Begin time : Mon Nov 10 11:28:01 2015 Begin rpmdb : 538:541464668d769a2bb7dbfc8337e305ab6db9fb47 End time : 11:28:03 2014 (2 seconds) End rpmdb : 539:c8c53419da0ae4cba61f019df443d3c10593a208 User : root Return-Code : Success Command Line : install setools-console Transaction performed with: Installed rpm-4.11.1-16.el7.x86_64 @anaconda Installed yum-3.4.3-118.el7.centos.noarch @anaconda Installed yum-plugin-fastestmirror-1.1.31-25.el7_0.noarch @updates Packages Altered: Install setools-console-3.3.7-46.el7.x86_64 @base
If the date of the database for the system file integrity tool is more than thirty days older than the begin time from the previous command, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The system must not have extraneous accounts with special privileges, such as shutdown, halt, and reboot.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>Special privilege accounts allow for the execution of commands on the system that should only be undertaken once a user logs in with their normal credentials and assumes a superuser role. This allows for accountability for the action and requires two authentication sequences to take place before command is executed.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext: Remove all extraneous accounts with special privileges from the “/etc/passwd” and “/etc/shadow” files.

check.check-content:
Verify that special privilege account do not exist on the system
Check for the presence of special privilege accounts on the system with the following commands:
# grep /sbin/shutdown /etc/passwd # grep /sbin/halt /etc/passwd # grep /sbin/reboot /etc/passwd
If any accounts are returned, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/sysctl.conf file must be owned by root.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot and must be protected. Unauthorized modification of these files resulting from improper ownership could compromise the system's kernel configuration.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the owner of the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chown root /etc/sysctl.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file is owned by root.
Check the owner of the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/sysctl.conf -rw------- 1 root root 47 Oct 12 17:13 sysctl.conf
If the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file has an owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/sysctl.conf file must be group-owned by root.
Rule.description:

Unauthorized modifications resulting from improper group ownership may compromise the system’s kernel configuration.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Set the group owner of the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file to root with the following command:
# chgrp root /etc/sysctl.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file is group owned by root.
Check the group owner of the “/etc/sysctl.conf” with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/sysctl.conf -rw------- 1 root root 47 Oct 12 17:13 sysctl.conf
If the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file has a group owner other than root, this is a finding.

Rule.title: The /etc/sysctl.conf file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
Rule.description: <VulnDiscussion>The sysctl.conf file specifies the values for kernel parameters to be set on boot and must be protected. File permissions greater than 0600 on the sysctl.conf file could allow an unauthorized user to view or modify sensitive information pertaining to system boot instructions.</VulnDiscussion><FalsePositives></FalsePositives><FalseNegatives></FalseNegatives><Documentable>false</Documentable><Mitigations></Mitigations><SecurityOverrideGuidance></SecurityOverrideGuidance><PotentialImpacts></PotentialImpacts><ThirdPartyTools></ThirdPartyTools><MitigationControl></MitigationControl><Responsibility></Responsibility><IAControls></IAControls>
Rule.fixtext:
Change the mode of the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file to “0600” with the following command:
# chmod 0600 /etc/sysctl.conf

check.check-content:
Verify that the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file has a mode of “0600” or less permissive.
Check the mode of the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file with the following command:
# ls –al /etc/sysctl.conf -rw------- 1 root root 47 Oct 12 17:13 sysctl.conf
If the “/etc/sysctl.conf” file has a mode more permissive than “0600”, this is a finding.
